	<review>
		<date>2002-08-11</date>
		<username>bournerdan@hotmail.com</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Unfortunately not so very groovy......</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>To be honest, I was never a big fan of the original movie although I admit it had it's moments and I thought the whole concept at least had some shreds of imagination and invention on the part of Mr Myers. The second one was probably actually an improvement in my opinion, more laughs and more time on screen given to the best character Dr Evil. So with that in mind I went to see the third installment hoping that the improvement would continue. Well, to say that this was not the case would be an understatement. Constant rehashes of jokes that people found funny the first time around reek of a poverty of ideas. The once hilarious dialogue between Scott and Dr Evil is suddenly shamefully off the mark. Also, can someone please tell me why Beyonce Knowles was included in this film???? This is a comedy film right? So why has a very average RNB singer been drafted in to play the leading lady???? Not a single laugh in sight when Beyonce is anywhere near the camera. Plus let's be truly honest, Austin Powers Three introduces us to one of the most truly unfunny characters in film history - Goldmember...A roller skating foreigner with gold genitals and a skin disease, let the hilarity ensue. Scott Evil's reluctance to follow in his fathers footsteps was the one thing that made him funny, so what do they do in this film? They make him decide to follow in his fathers footsteps, real sensible. Fred Savage is drafted in for a one joke gag that Mike Myers decides to play about...oh...a thousand or so times, trouble being it isn't that funny in the first place. I think I laughed maybe twice and then it was just in response to the psychical abuse bestowed upon Mini Me which although humourous, not really all that inventive, or original. Don't get me wrong, I love a slice of mindless humour but for me Goldmember adds absolutely nothing at all on the first two, same gags not done so well. Oh and before I forget, why oh why oh why did they decide to bring back Fat B*****d??????? I mean, I thought it was universally known how rubbish that character was??? Surely even Mike Myers got the message on that one??This is honestly the first film I ever saw where the most entertaining part is the opening credits, apart from the horribly misjudged Britney cameo that is. So yeah, go and see Goldmember with your mates after a few drinks on a friday or saturday night and it might raise the gills, otherwise, hire something truly funny out from the video store, like 'Fargo' for instance.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-08-11</date>
		<username>Andrew Schrader (sa013@msn.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Oh, Hell NO!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I cannot begin to describe how monumentally disappointed I was with this film. I am a huge fan of Austin Powers but this has nearly ruined it for me!Mike Myers has completely lost sight of the genius that made Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery the film that it was. The original concept was brilliant. It was funny, witty and original and was an excellent lampoon of the secret agent/spy genre, sending up everything from James Bond to In Like Flint. This vision was somewhat lost in Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me but it was still a good sequel. The gags were faster and, in some cases, funnier. Distinctly different from the original, Spy Who Shagged Me was witty and original and gave us the unique Mini-Me! And, lest we forget, the scene where Dr. Evil's chair breaks down. "I need an old priest and a young priest! The power of Christ compels you, the power of Christ compels you!"Sadly, the wit, humour and originality has been completely lost and what we're left with is a badly made, shoddy, jumbled-up mess of a film. It has clearly been the subject of some pretty sloppy editing, sudden script changes and, possibly, visionary disputes between writer (Myers) and director (Jay Roache).The storyline behind 'Goldmember' is completely inexplicable and I'm not even going to bother writing a blerb about the plot because I honestly can't tell you what this film was about, I haven't a clue! This is a shame because this was one of the funniest parts of the first two films. Dr. Evil's plans were stupid but they were exactly the kind of stupid plans that the old Bond villains would have deemed feasible! Even Drax or Blofeld would have had trouble swallowing Dr. Evil's plan in Goldmember.This problem with the plot is repeated with the cast. Almost every character is apparently pointless and all the time traveling left me so confused I didn't know where or when we were supposed to be half the time. Goldmember himself is a completely stupid character, who can only be described as a pointless, half naked Dutchman with a solid gold wedding tackle, who eats his own skin! Sir Michael Caine was, however, excellent but God knows why he agreed to do it.The underrated Seth Green reprises his role as Dr. Evil's wayward son, Scott Evil. Sadly, Myers chose to downplay the awkward father/son relationship aspect of the Evils and tried to make them bond in this film. The result was nowhere near as funny as the dysfunctional relationship in the first two films. Verne Troyer returns as Mini-Me, Michael York as Basil Exposition, Robert Wagner as Number Two, and Mindy Sterling as Frau Farbissina. The only other notable addition was The Wonder Years' Fred Savage as 'The Mole'. The Mole, who has a huge hairy mole on his face, caused the only other remotely funny scene in the film, where Austin Powers makes a Basil Fawltyesque attempt, unsuccessfully, not to mention the mole (incidentally, however, we had already seen this in the trailer).The Austin Powers francise has been horrifically corrupted by Hollywood and the product-placement isn't even funny anymore (see also, Spider-man, Men In Black 2, etc.). The celebrity guest stars are numerous as usual and include: Tom Cruise, Gwyneth Paltrow, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito, John Travolta, Steven Spielberg (annoyingly referred to as "Sir Steve" throughout his stint), Britney Spears, and Ozzy Osborne and Family. The only good guest-spot went to Nathan Lane, who also delivered one of the only other funny segments of the film.Also, Jeanette Charles has been hired once again to play the "Queen of England" in the scene where Austin in knighted, despite bearing absolutely no resemblance to our own dear Queen whatsoever. Just to annoy me, as an ardent monarchist, if you care (which nobody will), she wears the Sash of the Order of the Garter over the wrong shoulder and the Garter Star on the wrong side. (This would normally have amused me, as in The Spy Who Shagged Me where the army colonel has completely the wrong uniform on, but because the film was so crap it just compounded my annoyance.)The whole film is just awful and crushingly disappointing and myself and my friends left the cinema close to tears. Only real die-hard Austin Powers fans will enjoy this film, the kind of nerds that will enjoy it no matter how lame it becomes or people whose sense of humour is so lacking in sophistication that penis jokes are all that is required. I myself require a little bit more.Once last bone of contention, from my own petty nationalistic point of view. I always liked Austin Powers because of the Union Jacks everywhere and because, like the Bond films, it made you proud to be British. It was suddenly like it was cool again, a far cry from all the Hollywood villains with upper-class English accents. Sadly, Myers (a Canadian and, thus, a Commonwealth cousin) must be under some pressure from the Hollywood machine. We saw the usually Union Flag bedecked opening sequence have a few star-spangled banners thrown in and Elizabeth Hurley's Vanessa Kensington was replaced with the more than welcome sight of Heather Graham's Felicity Shagwell in The Spy Who Shagged Me. Now, in Goldmember, we get yet another American, this time Beyonce Knowles as Foxxy Cleopatra. Miss Knowles may be a good singer but her acting ability makes Liz Hurley look like she went to RADA.For God sake don't watch this film unless you're a brain-dead vegetable. Buy the first, rent the second but forget this one. I wish I could.1/10 (and that just because of The Mole!)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Oh groovy baby! "Goldmember" is the funniest of the series!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Austin Powers In Goldmember" was laugh-out-loud from beginning to end. We even got some cameoes: Britney Spears, Steven Spielberg, John Travolta, Gwyneth Paltrow, Tom Cruise, Quincy Jones, Burt Bacharach, The Osbournes, Kevin Spacey, and Danny DeVito.The movie is still shagadelic. There were even twin Japanese sisters named Fook Yu and Fook Mi. My 3 favorite scenes and they're not in particular: 1. The office scene with Austin Powers and Mini-Me. 2. The beginning where they're making a AP movie and Cruise plays AP, Paltrow palys Dixie Normous, Spacey plays Dr. Evil, and Danny Devito plays Mini-Me, and the scene when flips the bird at the screen was very funny. Even Spielberg was directing it. 3. Whenever The Mole shows up every time on the screen. (mole)From what I heard, the movie was originally 3 hours long and they cut out half of it, including: one with Mustafa (Will Farell), the younger Number 2 (Rob Lowe), and the first two AP babes: Vanessa Kensington (Elizabeth Hurley) and Felicity Shagwell (Heather Graham). (mooooooolllllleeee)Oh, well. That's why we have DVD and I hope they put the deleted footage in the DVD. But, if you enjoyed the first 2 AP movies, then you'll enjoy "Austin Powers In Goldmember." Yeah, baby, yeah!! (moley moley moley moley moley)A+ 13/13 ****** (out of ****** stars)</fullReview>

		<username>videofreak2002 (videofreak2002@aol.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Oh groovy, baby!!! Austin Powers is back!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When "Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery" came out in 1997, it made almost $60 million at the B.O., but, became a big hit in the video stores. In 1999, the sequel, "Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me," made more money opening weekend then the original at the B.O. and grossed over $200 million, making Austin Powers one of the funniest characters ever. Now, in 2002, "Austin Powers in Goldmember" has just been released and the movie is more groovier. Besides Mr. Powers, we have all the characters back: Dr. Evil (Mike Myers, who also played Ausitn Powers), Mini-Me (Verne Troyer), Number 2 (Robert Wagner), Frau Farbissina (Mindy Sterling), Scott Evil (Seth Green), Fat Bastard (Myers), and Basil Exposition (Michael York). And we have new characters: Foxy Cleopatra (Beyonce Knowles), Number 3/The Mole (Fred Savage), Nigel Powers (Michael Caine), and Goldmember (Myers). What's also surprising are the cameos: Tom Crusie, Gwyneth Paltrow, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito, Steven Speilberg, Burt Bacharach, Quincy Jones, John Travolta, Britney Spears, and The Osbournes.But, after the 1st and 2nd, is the 3rd still funny? Yes. And it's funnier. The jokes are still coming strong (moley moley moley moley) and the new jokes are much funnier (mole) and we see Dr. Evil rapping to Jay-Z's "It's A Hard Knocked Life" (mole mole). Even more surprising is the ending. It's very surprising. If you want to shag for the third time, then "Goldmember" is your ticket. Yeah, baby, yeah (moooooooooolllllllllleeeeeeeeee)!!!A+ 13/13 ****** (out of ****** stars)</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-11</date>
		<username>Ryan Love</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Tired, shagged out series. PS: Woody Allen?!?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The first two Austin Powers movies were funny. The third one is a pretty bad rehash. The jokes are just tired now. Some of the parts were rather funny, but this just wasn't up to par with the rest of the series. The humor has slipped further and further down the scale, ending (I hope) here with Goldmember. This one is almost exclusively toilet humor. That, of course, is exactly what most people want.And I have to respond to the person who thought Goldmember parodied Woody Allen. I'll grant that Austin resembles Woody Allen with his glasses, but I don't think it's an intentional parody. The subtitle humor was NOT a parody of Annie Hall--parodying requires some sort of resemblance to the original work, and aside from the subtitles, that is non-existent. The scene in question was not showing their thoughts, only an understandable version of the words. It is, however, still derived from an earlier film: the original (and better) version is in Airplane. If anywhere, I think that's where the reference lies. I haven't seen Purple Rose of Cairo or Stardust yet, so I can't comment on those. Personal opinion, while there might conceivably be some references to Allen (from what the user said, the end is close to Stardust), there is very little Woody Allen influence in Goldmember. Allen's humor was a LOT better, and I couldn't help but feel a little sad when his name was mentioned along with this movie.A few funny moments keep Goldmember from being a complete waste of time, but I really wish I had waited for video. 3/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-08-10</date>
		<username>VenomX</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Good comedy, weak script, great jokes</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Austin Powers started off as a small James Bond-spoofing title back in 1997. Since then, it has grown into a giant marketing juggernaut that has held a firm grip on summer comedies since it's debut. The original had a small budget, but excelled in its script, which was filled with visual gags and memorable quotes, as well as the predominant Bond spoofs it contained. The sequel came out two years later, and received a moderately mixed reception. Some were disappointed with it, as they saw the recycling of old gags and the introduction of more bathroom humour. I, on the other hand, saw it as a worthy sequel that wasn't as good as the original, but could still hold it's own. Now, we have another sequel that allows the Austin Powers series to become a trilogy, a large honour in franchises.The plot goes like this: Dr. Evil has hatched a plan where he will recruit the evil villain Goldmember from 1975, he will kidnap Austin Powers' father in the present and hide him in the 70's, meanwhile, he begins a plan to pull a asteroid into Earth with a tractor beam. Austin must now team up with his former girlfriend Foxxy Cleopatra to save his father and defeat the evil Dr. Evil.Before you see Goldmember, keep in mind that this movie is a lot sillier and crazier than the previous ones. Unlike the first two, this one tends to keep its plot a little contained and focus completely on its jokes and gags, many of which are hilarious. Some scenes are recycled again, but have been turned around so they appear more original (like the "objects that looks suggestive on the radar screen'). The celebrity cameos that were used are really hysterical (I'm not going to spoil anything for you, it's much more funny if you don't expect it) and the spoofing in here was nicely done (a little more subtle this time around). The jokes are what drive this movie, the plot is meaningless as time goes on, and that's one problem. In the first two, a decent plot was used to back the movie up, in this one; it's a little absent. One reason for this is the fact that the editing job is a little poor, so as a result, you really can't tell what is going on sometimes (I had to watch it a second time to understand it).See this one for the humour, just leave your brain at the door and enjoy, that's wait this movie is aiming for. Not as good as the original, about on par with the second one. To be honest, they should end this series now, Goldmember showed a few signs of franchise fatigue as the movie went on, creating a fourth one would just be milking the series.7/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-10</date>
		<username>randdog (randdog@mac.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Meyers maintains his comic genious</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In my opinion many of the critics have been overly harsh in their reviews of the latest "Austin Powers" movie. Is this movie on par with "Citizen Kane?" No, nor was it ever intended to be. Mike Meyers is the one individual who can take crude and sophmoric humor and make it genuinely unoffensive and funny at the same time. It's his gift, which he uses well in this third installment of the "Austin Powers" series.The opening sequence of the movie, which features some wonderfully utilitzed cameos was worth the price of admission all on its own. The starpower and Hollywood muscle utilized in the first five minutes of the film demonstrates that Meyers is worthy of our attention. Meyers' gifted comic characters are skillfully represented with vulnerability and sensitivity that go far beyond the comic intentions of the film its self. Whether it be the vulnerability of "Fat Bastard," the insecurities of "Dr. Evil," or the "always misses the boat" silliness of the film's title character, Meyers manages to give each one a soul that makes his audience care.Critics be damned, the third installment of "Austin Powers" is a "gotta see" movie.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-06</date>
		<username>mcquestion</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>It's obvious what Mike Myers was trying to do</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>SPOILERS CONTAINED HEREINI have to say that I disagree with Dennis Miller in his opinion that Dana Carvey is the most talented SNL player ever. IMHO that title is reserved for Mike Myers. That being said, the latest Austin Powers offering is not the sterling example of comic hilarity that the first two were. I absolutely adored Austin Powers 1 and 2, but 3, while having some funny moments, lacked any of the big belly laughs and ultra hilarious moments that the first two had. Why is this? The answer is obvious. Myers was actually TRYING to make a film that tied up the first two and made it a trilogy, and sacrificed a lot of spontanaiety in the creative process. His fourth character in the series, Goldmember, is entirely unfunny and serves no purpose. That thing about him eating his own skin was pointless and grosser than any fat bastard floater joke. Speaking of FB, he's one of my favorite characters from the second film, but here it's obvious he's being added just to tie things up. He serves no purpose whatsoever, though he still gave me a few good chuckles.Meanwhile, Austin Powers himself has moved back to take a supporting character status in the last two films. The first one was about Austin's being a fish out of water in a new era, but after that, the real star of the films has always been Dr. Evil. The formerly hilarious supporting cast of Robert Wagner and Mindi Sterling are incidental in the film, and Scott Evil gets to develop, but loses the original intent behind his character. Beyonce Knowles is unfunny and untalented, and Fred Savage has never been funny. There have been comment made that this film seems completely disjointed, just randomness thrown together, and I echo that statement completely. The film wanders all over the place in an attempt to tie up all the loose ends in the films. What is forgotten is that there really isn't a need for such a thing in this kind of comedy. In Star Wars, maybe, but not Austin Powers.Still, there are funny moments in the film, ranging from Dr. Evil's revelation about his true connection to Austin ("I'm Dougie!") to Mini-Me's scene stealing as a double agent and becoming mini-Austin to Dr. Evil's "It's A Hard Knock Life" performance, to Fat Bastard's scenes, there is humour evident. Funnily enough, the superstar cameos at the beginning did little for me, other than the Speilberg moments with Austin (check out Speilberg's double hand springing away from his seat as the opening music hits, that was the funniest part for me). Tom Cruise and Paltrow left me cold, while Kevin Spacey and Devito were funny, it was so short it didn't really entertain me. Britney Spears was entirely unfunny and unentertaining in her short appearance. Like everything else about the pop diva, her appearance was cold, calculated, and entirely manufactured to do one thing: maintain her "cool factor" and not entertain. Actually, the funniest cameo IMHO was by Nathan Lane, who never says an actual word.All in all, it has it's moments, but compared to the hilarity offered by the first two films, it pales in comparison. I'm not worried, though, Myers has loads of untapped talent and I'm sure he has yet another batch of characters ready to amuse us with. Sadly, the Austin Powers era seems to be over.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>cestsibon</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Woody Allen's influence present throughout AP3</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Allen's Influence Present Throughout AP3Most of the kids that saw Austin Powers 3 may never have seen a Woody Allen movie. Some adults that saw it may have recognized that scene that emulated Annie Hall, but the movie also borrows from some of Allen's lesser known movies.A hand-drawn picture of Austin Powers was displayed in this movie, and it looked amazingly like Woody Allen. I dismissed this at first, though Powers had already jumped through a movie screen, coming to real life, alá Purple Rose of Cairo.Myers does not as much borrow, than parody the scene from Annie Hall. Which one? Why, the scene where Alvy and Annie speak meaningless garbage, while their true thoughts are displayed on-screen through subtitles. So Austin Powers and his father (Michael Caine) are in a room full of American girls. Caine suggests that they speak in "English." While saying things that could only be discernable by Brits, subtitles appear, informing us Americans what they mean.Finally when the plot ends happily, we feel as if we are watching Stardust Memories all over again. We are taken to the premiere where the actors have just finished watching Austin Powers 3. They applaud, then rise from their seats, just as in Stardust Memories. You can just feel Myers' overpowering affinity to Allen by paying homage to him, using this esoteric reference, while knowing it will fly over the heads of the majority of the crowd.However, I believe some people noticed what was going on. The point of this message is to ask, were there any other Allen movies that were parodied?</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Lame</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The saying goes: "the third time's the charm", right? Well, certainly not in this case. There isn't a single riotous moment in this film - nary a chuckle. It's obvious that Myers is mining the Austin Powers franchise for every last shekel, yet obviously hasn't any fresh ideas to deliver in exchange.Others have covered the plot, so I'll not get into this paltriness, but suffice to say that it's thin...by any standard. And the star turns are obnoxious. Hard to imagine that Mike Myers thought it would be a good idea to rip off the concept of Get Shorty, but indeed he did. 		<shortDescription>Truly Terrible</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I found the first of the trilogy to be average; the second I thought amusing. I was not therefore expecting AUSTIN POWERS 3: GOLDMEMBER to be so truly terrible.Forgetting the fact that the jokes are simply recycled from the previous movies; the plot, writing and direction were an embarrassment. 		<date>2002-08-05</date>
		<username>CutiePie0211</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Definitely worth seeing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I absolutely loved this movie. It had me in fits of laughter throughout the whole thing. Goldmember is much more clever than the first two films in the trilogy. It does have a few somewhat vulgar scenes, but overall it is hilarious. Mike Myers is as always ingenious and hysterical in his roles as Austin Powers, Dr. Evil, Fat Bastard, and now, Goldmember. Seth Green is also rediculously funny as Dr.Evil's son Scott, and of course, the lovely Beyonce from Destiny's Child is pretty good as Austin 'Danger' Powers's counterpart. This movie is definitely worth seeing.</fullReview>

Even the spy movie satire elements were nothing that other movies hadn't poked fun at dozens of times before.When the first sequel appeared a couple of years back, a few of the jokes still had enough life left in them to repeat one last time, but now that Goldmember is here, I assure you, all remaining humor has long since been wrung out of them.If you want to see yet another try at the sugegstive shadow scene, the fembots (this time with a celebrity cameo in a desparate attempt to make them funny again), more clone jokes, and even more of the father/son conflict than you saw before, then by all means, feel free to go for another helping, and don't let my criticism stop you, but don't blame me if you feel like you've seen it all before.</fullReview>

		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Tries too hard</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film has its moments but they are simply moments with a lot of failed jokes in between. The first Austin Powers was groundbreaking and excellent, the second played off of that and was unusually good for a sequel although not as good as the first, and this latest third installment just struggles throughout.The opening sequences lend themselves of the humor from the first, but they quickly fade. Many of the jokes from the first two are simply reused and are no longer funny since we know what is going to happen either from seeing the previous films or the many parodies that stemmed from them.Mike Myers still has potential in the characters of Austin and Dr. Evil and both do have good scenes but there was a lot more that could have been done but was not. Goldmember is rather 2 dimentional and Fat Bastard who was excellent from the second installment, seemed to be added in as an afterthought. Suprisingly, Scott seems to be the most developed character in this film.The franchise has been milked for all it is worth and is in evident decline. Unfortunatly there is an opening for a fourth film. Please, leave the franchise with some dignity and do not make a fourth.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-08-05</date>
		<username>cestsibon</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Woody Allen's influence present throughout AP3</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Allen's Influence Present Throughout AP3Most of the kids that saw Austin Powers 3 may never have seen a Woody Allen movie. Some adults that saw it may have recognized that scene that emulated Annie Hall, but the movie also borrows from some of Allen's lesser known movies.A hand-drawn picture of Austin Powers was displayed in this movie, and it looked amazingly like Woody Allen. I dismissed this at first, though Powers had already jumped through a movie screen, coming to real life, alá Purple Rose of Cairo.Myers does not as much borrow, than parody the scene from Annie Hall. Which one? Why, the scene where Alvy and Annie speak meaningless garbage, while their true thoughts are displayed on-screen through subtitles. So Austin Powers and his father (Michael Caine) are in a room full of American girls. Caine suggests that they speak in "English." While saying things that could only be discernable by Brits, subtitles appear, informing us Americans what they mean.Finally when the plot ends happily, we feel as if we are watching Stardust Memories all over again. We are taken to the premiere where the actors have just finished watching Austin Powers 3. They applaud, then rise from their seats, just as in Stardust Memories. You can just feel Myers' overpowering affinity to Allen by paying homage to him, using this esoteric reference, while knowing it will fly over the heads of the majority of the crowd.However, I believe some people noticed what was going on. The point of this message is to ask, were there any other Allen movies that were parodied?</fullReview>
	</review>

You and this friend have a great time until the changes become evident and then its almost as if you have a new friend...and some of the changes you don't like, but you still want this friend, so you accept and move on. This is what one must do when experiencing Austin Powers in Goldmember. Austin and the usual gang are back, but there are quite a few changes. These changes make for both an engaging and fun way to look at the AP franchise, but also a way to kill it.I had a fun time with Goldmember and you should too...</fullReview>

		<username>jackie623</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Although Austin loses a bit of his mojo, "Goldmember" finds humor in supporting roles</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>(lots of spoilers ahead) I didn't find Austin Powers as shag-a-delic in this third installment. Unlike the first two films, "Goldmember" begins with a bright spark - undeniably the best opening sequence I have ever seen (although Britney seemed unnecessary - I kept thinking if I watched this movie on DVD in 10 years if I'd have to explain who that girl is). Tom Cruise smiling at the camera, Kevin Spacey slowing putting his pinky to his mouth, and Danny Devito flipping off the camera were fantastic. The flashback sequence to Dr. Evil &amp; Austin in college further ignited my curiosity for the rest of the film. Unfortunately this flame quickly dies out after the first hour.What happened to Austin's sexy sidekick? I didn't think Heather Graham measured up to Elizabeth Hurley, but at least she had chemistry with Myers. Beyonce Knowles' character Foxy Cleopatra is not useful to the plot and should have been left on the cutting room floor. She's supposed to be a spy, but it seems more like she's just following Austin around the set, waiting for him to make the first move. While the audience laughed at Austin's former sidekicks, Foxy's mantra "whole lotta woman" gets tired. Dr. Evil and Mini Me carry this film, as they did in the second film of the series. As a result of the somewhat-serious storyline with Austin's father, new characters Goldmember and Sexy Cleopatra fail to add laughs or significance to the plot. Fat Bastard was awful in AP2, and is still awful. The Mole, TERRIBLE. Austin not shagging anybody, TERRIBLE.Overall, I give the film a 7 out of 10. Austin Powers' fans will appreciate the inside jokes and repetitive humor. Dr. Evil and Mini Me are fantastic! Not enough Frau or Number 2. Mini Me is the only one who has a comical chemistry with Cleopatra ... more toilet humor of course. I truly appreciate toilet humor. I'm curious to see what Myers will come up with next for the character of Scott Evil. Scott was so original in the original, I don't know where else he can go now. I think Myers should give Mini Me a shot next to take over the world.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-08-04</date>
		<username>Benny246</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Pure stupid, infintile, filthy, dirty, juvenile fun</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Perhaps I should begin this review with a brief history of my experiences with Austin Powers. The first movie I saw when I was in sixth grade and me being a huge James Bond fan my mother offered to take me, both of us unaware of the barrage of sexual innuendo. I was forced to walk out and for many years after that I despised Austin Powers and felt that it represented the low-brow humor of my generation which I was "so much above."When, "The Spy Who Shagged Me" came out I went with a friend who really wanted to see it, and it being his birthday, I was unable to avoid it. Needless to say I laughed my ass off, at first unwillingly, then, after a while, I just couldn't control it anymore. Since than I have seen the rest of the original, but only in sections.I went to see Goldmember the second day it was out. The audience was primed, everyone was excited and it was a total laugh riot. Complete with movie riffs dance numbers and, of course, fart jokes, this was equal to The Spy Who Shagged Me, if not better. I was unfettered by any superiority complexes and I just laughed. Foxxy was a great character, even if she herself didn't have any funny lines. She didn't need to! Beyonce Knowles was the perfect straight man (err, woman) for Myers, in all his forms, and for Nathan Lane, in his brief, but hilarious, cameo. I ended up seeing this one twice and it makes me regret seeing the first and second films only once.The opening sequence was great and the movie went up from there. Although I found Fat Bastard unfunny I was cracking up at just about everything else. So what if some of the jokes were reused. The point is that this movie contained riffs on the spy genre and on the original two Austin Powers' movies, which, if you think about it, just stole scenes from James Bond movies, which were just as cliche, and twisted them around to make them funny. The first and second Austin Powers' funniest themes were ripped off of older movies (bald evil genius who has a furry white cat and elaborate plans to kill his enemies and tae over the world that never quite work and never make any sense, evil henchman, people who don't die or who escape death through extremely unplausible and unsensible situations, an oversexed superspy, a female lea whose only job is to be sexy, the list goes on).The point is that after three movies Myers can juggle four characters and keep them all fresh and funny.There was never much originality to the Austin Powers' franchise. The jokes were just raunchier than what people were used to. But they all made people laugh. I don't rate the films as best or worst in the series, they are all good and Myers should be complimented for creating a smashing good time.P.S.: Word is that there were over forty minutes of deleted scenes which will show up on the DVD, one of which shows what happens to Felicity Shagwell (Heather Graham).</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-08-04</date>
		<username>neil-130 (gillespieneil@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Diminishing returns</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Goldmember delivers almost everything you can expect from the movie - most of the previous characters return to deliver their best gags from the first two movies, with enough new material added to the mix to make it worth watching. Unfortunately, the new characters and plot points suffer from being chronically under written - the eponymous Goldmember being a good example. Is he supposed to be funny just because he's Dutch and therefore "weird"? Okay, a basis for a character, but surely it's got to be developed from there. The jokes and patter run much as in the previous movies, and are still quite funny, but the laughs are now in recognition rather than guffaw-inducing humour. I like the two previous movies, and I enjoyed this one, but it could have been a lot better with just a little more effort. Also, Austin seems to have become a shadow of himself in this movie. Where are all his women? And wasn't the whole joke with Austin the anachronism of this 60s persona trying to deal with the 90s? So why isn't Austin's 60s/70s clash, with a dash of turn-of-the-century hindsight/foresight, explored in this movie, when Austin goes back to find Goldmember? It would seem like an obvious, and interesting, joke but is never explored. Instead, these 'subtler' points from the first movie are replaced by cruder dick and fart gags. Still, a good movie but not great.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Austin Powers in Goldmember has got to be the most disappointing movies I've seen this year. Unfortunately, I could rant for an hour or two about the disgusting, offensive and generally un-funny situations Austin finds himself in during this latest episode. The introduction of Austin's father is the one saving element of the film. The character is truly how one would picture the International Man of Mystery's pop. The great opening credits, a play off of subtitles and a flashback produced the only heartfelt laughs. Goldmember would have induced vomiting if I had eaten more popcorn. He was hideous to look at and generally unpleasant (which would've been alright...if he was funny). Take that and throw in the Osbournes. And Britney Spears. Pretty unappealing, eh? The jokes were either old, crude, or just plain stupid. Beyonce was great...for what she had to work with. Her character was cliched and abrasive. My rating...5. 		<username>Ellen</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Groovy, baby!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I thought that this film was good. Normally, slap-stick humour applied in films as a way of replacing a good story-line does not remotely engage, interest, or make me laugh in any shape or form. I dislike films such as There's Something About Mary and Scary Movie. I haven't as yet seen Austin Powers: The spy who shagged me, so I cannot comment on the trilogy as a whole, but from what I've seen, it is very funny. Like the aforementioned films, there is no original story-line, but the humour is definitely more intelligent, and it is used to complement, rather than compensate for, the story-line. As opposed to the take-offs in Scary Movie, the references to other films (such as Silence of the Lambs and The Italian Job) were subtle, which meant that they were invariably more funny. And a lot of the humour was genuinely hilarious, such as the exchanges between Scott and Dr Evil.Do not go into the cinema expecting a striking screen-play; enjoy it for the slick comedy that it is!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-03</date>
		<username>tonythetiger</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>"Funny" is an opinion, and my opinion on Goldmember is: "very funny"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Yes, some movies are meant to be dissected, analyzed, scrutinized... but not this movie baby! One word says it best; entertaining! Oh, I could say things like "the plot was weak" or "some jokes were repeated" or "it was stupid". But why should I? I'll leave that to other hard-to-please movie go-ers. I loved it. I laughed, and I cried from laughter. What type of movie is it? It's a FUN movie and also visually pleasing. The jokes are very funny indeed, but it's mostly in the way that they are conveyed, and the interaction between the characters that make them ridiculously hilarious. This movie is not meant to please film school graduates. It's a C-O-M-E-D-Y !! No, it's not for everyone, to be sure. But if you have a similar type of sense of humour as several million other people who appreciate Austin Powers movies do, than you will enjoy Goldmember. If it's not your type of humour, than don't. Heck, some people find other movies funny when I don't. One's sense of humour can be very different from the next person. That's what makes us unique. It is impossible to make a comedy that will make everyone laugh. That's why comedies are probably the most difficult genre of movie to make. One thing's for sure though; the Austin Powers series has been funnier than most other comedy movies in North America, based on the public's accounts (forget box office sales). Mike Myers has succeeded in making more people laugh than most of us, and for that I thank him.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>i wasnt expecting much out of goldmember. having read many bad reviews i thought i would be in the majority. international man of mystery was definetly the best A.P. movie. the spy who shagged me wasn't as good. fat bastard and mini me were unwelcome,heather graham was terrible and they wrote off IMOM by turning vanessa into a fembot. but goldmember was better than TSWSM. although some jokes were rehashed and the cast was way too large, it still made me laugh. goldmember was a terrible idea and wasn't funny. michael caine did a good job as nigel powers. beyonce knowles was surprisingly good as foxxy cleopatra, but still no liz hurley. fat bastard and mimi me were a little better this time round. and still great performances from seth green, mindy sterling and robert wagner. the cameos at the start were definitely the films laughing point. number 3 was the best and most welcome new character, although the films soundtrack was awful. overall, very entertaining. 7 out of 10</fullReview>

		<username>kscaduncan</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Just as good as the first two.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I loved both International Man Of Mystery and The Spy Who Shagged Me so I was looking forward to this. I was not disappointed. Michael Caine was superb as Nigel Powers. An excellent piece of casting. Mike Myers is also great as Austin, Dr. Evil, Fat Bastard and new character Goldmember. Verne Troyer is also wonderful. The best parts of the film are the cameos at the beginning and towards the end of the film. I won't mention the stars featured but it's worth waiting for. As much as I would like to see more Austin Powers, I think now's the time to stop. Everything has been wrapped up and there isn't really any other direction the franchise can go to.To the makers of the film: Quit while you're ahead. Don't let the saga drag on and on. Look at the Friday The 13th or Halloween franchises!Overall, a great comedy film which is well worth watching.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-03</date>
		<username>wink12345</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Mike Myers is not a comic genius.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After seeing the first two Austin Powers movies which I found funny, I decided to see the third one expecting the same hilarious laughs that I had in watching the previous film The Spy Who Shagged Me. Austin Powers in Goldmember does have some funny moments but a lot of scenes are just recycled jokes from the first two. The thing that bugged me the most about this film was how Mike Myers resorted to being more and more gross just to get laughs (ie. any scene with Fat Bastard). He seems to think that bodily fluids and functions are the most hilarious things on earth. He is funny in scenes but is no comic genius like a lot of people are calling him. Another thing that bothered me was a long setup for one line involving "Mr.Roboto". It was not funny and I knew it was coming as soon as I heard the word Roboto. The bottom line is that Mike Myers can be funny even if most of his humour does involve bodily functions (The Spy Who Shagged Me). But in this film he goes too far and uses too many stale jokes. I give it two stars out of five.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-03</date>
		<username>Ellen</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Groovy, baby!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I thought that this film was good. Normally, slap-stick humour applied in films as a way of replacing a good story-line does not remotely engage, interest, or make me laugh in any shape or form. I dislike films such as There's Something About Mary and Scary Movie. I haven't as yet seen Austin Powers: The spy who shagged me, so I cannot comment on the trilogy as a whole, but from what I've seen, it is very funny. Like the aforementioned films, there is no original story-line, but the humour is definitely more intelligent, and it is used to complement, rather than compensate for, the story-line. As opposed to the take-offs in Scary Movie, the references to other films (such as Silence of the Lambs and The Italian Job) were subtle, which meant that they were invariably more funny. And a lot of the humour was genuinely hilarious, such as the exchanges between Scott and Dr Evil.Do not go into the cinema expecting a striking screen-play; enjoy it for the slick comedy that it is!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I thought this movie was one of the best movies I have seen in a long, long, time. I don't understand why so many people thought this was the worst of the three Austin Power movies. This is better than the second, and tons better than the first. It has a much better plot, and the characters have even developed a lot more. I still like the original characters, and most of of the new characters are well thought up, including, Goldmember, Foxxy Cleapatra, Nigel Powers, and Mole. Possible SpoilersThere were some things I didn't like about the new film, and they are, -The Cameos. In my opinion that was so stupid. Who thought up that idea? What was so clever about that? -The Ending. The ending was kind of neat, and kind of stupid. It was cool that Austin Powers and Dr. Evil are actually brothers, but, I don't think Dr. Evil should have turned good. Now, how are they going to make a 4th one? Some people are probablyshouting out for joy, but I'm not. They are really good movies. They will have to think something up.This is my disappointment on the whole Austin Powers Trilogy. Too Raunchy. Most of it is not that bad, but alot of the sexual stuff gets kind of uncomfortable. I wish they could tone it down a little bit, and it would make it alot more enjoyable. Other than a couple minor details, it was a fantastic movie. I can't wait to get it on DVD. My rating is 10/10!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-02</date>
		<username>suquintet</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Austin Powers in Cruddymovie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>From the opening shots of the newest installment in the Austin Powers series it becomes apparent that much more money has been spent than in previous films. It also becomes clear that jokes that seem like they'll be funny ultimately fall flat. Furthermore, jokes that seem like they'll fall flat from the beginning do in fact fall flat, and are then rammed in our faces at least three more times for us cringe.The film is loaded with potentially funny celebrity cameos. It is also loaded with jokes that had no business making it through editing. (Austin: (After destroying a Fembot Britney Spears) Oops, I did it again.)Product placement runs wild through the film as well.Watching `Goldmember' is for the most part tragically embarrassing. It occurred to me about 20 minutes into the film that it didn't even seem like it was Mike Myers playing his characters, but rather someone who looked just like Mike Myers but could only do a sloppy impression. Austin himself is immensely pathetic. Dr. Evil seems to take on some strange Canadian traits. Fat Bastard...was dead, was he not? Well, anyway, he's annoying here. And last and least is Goldmember, an annoying and highly underdeveloped character. (How do we know he likes gold? Because he says he likes gold, that's it.) Other actors don't have much luck either. Beyonce Knowles does practically nothing as Foxy Cleopatra, although she admittedly seems like she could be fun. Michael Caine is good with what he has, or I should say, what little he has. Infact, the only consistently funny character is Mini Me, who is suprisingly hilarious in all of his scenes.Part of the problem may be that there are so many `things' the Powers movies always do, that this film is stifled by having to go out of its way to do them. A very unsatisfying series of `It's a (insert body part name here)' should have been cut, rather than kept only to keep with tradition.When the movie is funny, which does happen, it is very funny. The rap with Dr. Evil and Mini Me in prison is hilarious, the fight between Austin and Mini Me is hilarious. Some jokes about urination and childbirth are also particularly funny. These rare moments don't come closing to making up for the general schlock-ish feel of the film. This Austin Powers is unfunny, predictable and utterly forgettable.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-08-02</date>
		<username>(ezzy_ezzy@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.2</score>

I cant see how anyone can relate in anyway to this film, it lacks in comedy from start to finish. Goldmember is the most unfunny character i have ever seen, same as Dr. Evil was potrayed badly in this one. Michael Caine as austins dad? i dont mean to keep moaning but come on, how is that funny? Pointing out a mole on someones face just sucks too, ahhh i dunno im just angry about wasting my money at the cinema, go see it if ya wanna be disappointed!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-08-02</date>
		<username>perni</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Not the best of the AP series, but still fun</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After a hectic driving experience and a quick scurry to the popcorn and candy stand, we were in our seats for the new Goldmember flick. Let me just say that for right now, this is not my favorite AP sequel, but it does have its moments. Mike Meyers is a very funny man, and once again he brings an amazing range of character and humor to his four different roles (Austin, Dr. Evil, Fat Bastard, and Goldmember). Mini-Me gets his time in the spotlight, there's a very funny, cameo-packed opening, and some gross, albeit hilarious, body humor. Yes, we get a bunch of the old stuff (that looks like a giant--Johnson!), but Mike knows this and builds on it. Also, for all the hype around the title character, Dutch mastermind Goldmember isn't all that funny. Oh, and why does he eat his skin??? That's one odd choice that didn't result in a laugh. Michael Caine, who plays Austin's father, Nigel, doesn't get enough screen time and that's too bad. He was pretty good considering he played all of the material with a very faupish, England straight face. And now here are some spoilers for you: Beware!1. Cameos include Danny DeVito, Tom Cruise, John Travolta, Nathan Lane, the Osbournes, Steven Spielberg, and Fred Savage. All in all none of them were too inspiring (though I had read about the 'hilarious opener' beforehand, so the movie can't be faulted). Nathan Lane was the best of the bunch.2. Mini-Me becomes a good guy! Whouda thunk, huh? Verne Troyer gets a lot more screen time in Goldmember. The result? Ensuing hilarity!3. Turns out Dr. Evil is NOT Austin's father (as joked about in the second film), but his brother! Yep, turns out they were siblings all along. Needless to say, Dr. Evil joins sides with Austin to stop the dastardly Goldmember. Oh, and Dr. Evil's name is Dougy!4. Scott Evil becomes...evil! And in a stunt that pretty much confirms the next sequel, he becomes the new supervillain. Does that mean I want another AP movie? Maybe, but it has to be a little funnier than this.***/****</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-08-02</date>
		<username>Jerry Jones</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>A funny movie, but the weakest of the three.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>** 1/2Starring: Mike Myers, Beyonce Knowles, Michael Caine, and Verne Troyer.The follow-up to the hilarious Austin Powers franchise started in a hilarious opening. Things were looking quite up from there, except that it fell down a deep hill as the movie went on. The movie's plot is practically like the first two movie's plots. Austin having fun, he time travels, finds Dr. Evil, bathroom jokes, and so on. Austin Powers goes back to 1975 to find his kidnapped father. He meets up with Foxxy Cleopatra, a cross between pam Grier and Tamara Dobson. I really didn't like her character too much. She was funny at times, but she really was there for eye candy. Austin and Foxxy find a new foe, Goldmember. A strange Dutch who isn't that funny and makes you cringe more than laugh. They save Austin's father and must foil Dr. Evil and Goldmember's plan. This movie is full of bathroom humor, sometimes funny, sometimes stupid. They had some really good moments but not enough. I must also say that Fat Bastard was hardly in this, yet he stole every scene he was in. Dr. Evil and Minime also steal every scene they are in.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-02</date>
		<username>Phil Crandon</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>The beginning and middle were funny but the ending SUCKED (WARNING: MAJOR SPOILERS)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Although not a true fan, I enjoy the Austin Powers series and looked forward to the release of the third sequel. First, I must say that at first Beyoncé Knowles seemed to be out of place but as the movie went on she seemed fit in pretty well but was quite different than Elizabeth Hurley or Heather Graham were to the other Austin Powers movies. Although there wasn't much of a plotline (Dr. Evil hatched a plot to destroy the world but it wasn't as prominent as in the other two movies), there were plenty of jokes true to the storyline as well as entertaining action.Until the end, that is, where there was a huge plot twist that absolutely ruined the Austin Powers franchise.WARNING: LOTS OF SPOILERS AHEAD...SKIP THIS IF YOU HAVEN'T SEEN THE MOVIE!I have to say that the cameos in the beginning were absolutely hilarious, with my favorite being Danny DeVito as Mini-Me. The middle wasn't quite as funny, but it still has its entertaining moments. The Fat Bastard sumo wrestling scene, the Godzilla "copyright , infringement" scene, and Mini-Me's remarks to Foxy Cleopatra about "having a little clone inside herself" were some of my favorites. The one thing that really annoys me is that they made a big deal of going back in time to 1975 but were there for what, five minutes?Now for the end: As Scott Evil loses his trademark character and becomes "Evil", Nigel Powers (Austin Powers's father) reveals that he is Dr. Evil's father as well and they all come together in one big happy family...so Austin Powers and Dr. Evil (not to mention his entire organization) are friends. Aside from the fact that this was not funny at all, it also left very little room for a future installment (which I would have liked). Are the producers and writers trying to kill the franchise? What's next, Austin against Scott Evil? That would be awful.On a side note, Goldmember seemed to be a pointless addition.Overall, I would give Austin Powers in Goldmember a 6.5 out of 10. The first (Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery) was my favorite with The Spy who Shagged Me second and Goldmember third.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I just saw the movie today. I have seen the first two of the series and I have to say the plot here left me disappointed. I know, it's a spoof, it's a slapstick comedy -this ain't CINEMA - but still, I would have enjoyed a better story.On the other hand, good lord, I laughed too hard!!! Mike Myers is definitely the most talented SNL alum of recent times. The cameos are fantastic and casting Michael Caine as Austin's father worked perfectly.If you want to laugh out loud (a lot) and you don't need to be bothered with plot, don't miss it.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-01</date>
		<username>Dan Franzen (dfranzen70)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Austin is 'member' of gold-star club of coolness</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Yeah, baby, yeah! Austin Powers returns after being an International Man of Mystery and meeting up with The Spy Who Shagged Me. The always hip Mike Myers reprises his tour-de-force role, playing multiple roles, including Austin's archenemy, Dr. Evil; and the loquacious, foul Fat Bastard.This time around, Austin's just been knighted by the Queen of England - and his dad (a notorious no-show) isn't there to witness the great event. But no matter, soon Austin's off to stop the nefarious world-domination plot of Dr. Evil. Austin's transported to 1975 in a chic time machine and meets up with Foxy Cleopatra (Beyonce Knowles), a fellow agent. Foxy works for Goldmember, a sinister villain who happens to run a trendy disco club (where Foxy sings, of course). Goldmember's famous for his love of gold; his name stems from the fact that a certain part of his anatomy is golden, owing to a horrible smelting accident.Austin and Foxy know that Goldmember has been working on a plan for Dr. Evil, and they're sworn to stop him. That's about all of the plot you need to know now. There are some twists and turns, some absolutely hilarious. Along for the ride are, as in the past films, Seth Green as Scott Evil; Robert Wagner as Number Two, Michael York as Basil, and Verne Troyer as Mini-Me. Adding to the mayhem is Michael Caine with a somewhat smarmy bit as Austin's itinerant dad (although he's a bit under-used; just about any actor could have done the same in this role).The first thing one asks before seeing this film is, "Will this be as entertaining as the first two films?" The answer is yes, my friends, yes it is. There are a zillion jokes, and they're largely hit and miss, but those that hit are very funny. One of the misses is actually a hit, too - the opening sequence, which is a movie about Austin Powers - but not starring Austin as Austin, but rather an even more recognizable face, in one of many celebrity cameos.Any movie that has you rattling off its catch phrases as you depart the theater is a good movie, in my book. I kept saying, "Oh, behave!" even though there was no one else in the car. I even looked over at cars parked next to me at traffic lights, with my eyebrow raised and my mouth widening into a you-know-what grin. Yeah, baby, yeah! Wanna... shag?Goldmember's a lot of fun. Oh, don't worry, it's not a thinking man's movie. It's gross and disgusting - farts and eating your own skin play into the plot. The jokes can be a little on the ribald side, but there's nothing much you should warn your kids about. For the most part, if your kids loved the first two Austin Powers films, then this one's fine for them to see.Now, the cast. Myers is excellent as always in his multiple roles - in fact, I think there was more of him on the screen this time around than in the past, but that might have just been my own perception. Knowles, who's basically a novice when it comes to acting (she sings with the group Destiny's Child), is very appealing - spot on, as the Brits would say. "My name is Foxy Cleopatra, and I'm a whole LOTTA woman!" she tells Austin when they meet. Foxy's decked out in a big golden Afro wig and platform shoes - boy, who misses the fashion of the 70s, huh? - and peppers her speech with a lot of period slang.Only on celluloid could a guy with bad posture, terrible teeth, no dancing ability to speak of, a somewhat annoying bray, and a crooked haircut get all the hot women. I mean, look at this guy! In the first film, he got Elizabeth Hurley; in the second, it was Heather Graham. And now it's Beyonce Knowles! Who's next? Madonna?There were a couple of slow spots, but not very many. This one was a lot of fun, highly enjoyable.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Chris Anderson (drmrvandertramps)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Best of the three - Perhaps.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The first in the Austin Powers series was amazing. Simply amazing. It is because the first movie was so good that i have reservations about calling Goldmember the best. The second movie was awful. The reason for that was because the second movie focused on austin being a 60's british spy in 2000 north america (and then back in the 60's again) - the whole fish out of water angle had been done in the first movie and it was time to move on. They even killed mustafa again in that one, for the love of pete....In any event, when there were repeated gags in Goldmember, it was acknowledged. for instance, scott saying "Oh, this is the part where i... yadda yadda yadda". That said, contrary to popular belief there wasn't much repetition of jokes, nor was there as much overkill. I thought that Goldmember was remarkably well-done, very funny and i can say that while the jury's out on whether or not it's better than #1, it's infinitely better than #2 and has restored my faith in the series.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-01</date>
		<username>wendiegrrl</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>If you liked the other Austin Powers movies, you'll probably love this one, but if you thought number one or two were a little over the top, then save your money, this one will gross you out in ways you neve</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Mike Myers took our favourite shagadellic spy and went to the next level.It has relatively little storyline, barely any taste (well, actually, no taste if I'm being quite honest), characters that make you cringe, and a host of famous cameos that are thrown in there without any recourse to a plot - in short, it was a laugh-a-minute addition to the Austin Powers tradition of Anglo-Canadian humour consisting mainly of jokes about genitalia and a facial mole on the top lip of the grown-up boy in the Wonder Years, Fred Savage. Beyonce Knowles (from Destiny's Child, but don't hold that against her) did a fantastic Foxy Cleopatra who's only downfall, sadly, was that she wasn't in the movie enough for my liking !!Sufficed to say, if you liked the other Austin Powers movies, you'll probably love this one, but if you thought number one or two were a little over the top, then save your money, this one will gross you out in ways you never thought imaginable !!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Nicholas Schoenfeld (NickSDV@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>A worthy Sequel.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie is one of the few sequels, that lives up to its previous movies. It's funnier, it's bigger, it has more of everything that made the first two movies the same. The jokes are very funny the first time you watch the movie. After a while, they may get old. The movie is a spoof on many other movies, and it doesn't hold back one bit. It's gross at times, but that's what makes it so funny (in a very uncomfortable way). There are some very HUGE cameos in this movie by some very big stars that I won't give away, you have to see them for yourself, you will be surprised. Score 8 of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-07-31</date>
		<username>erigam</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Austin is Back Baby Yeah!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is the third installment of the Austin Powers Spy series. Personally, I thought it was the funniest of the three movies. It not only spoofs the Blaxploitation films of the 70's but Harry Potter and other up to date movies. It has a large ensemble of cameos most notably was Danny Devito as Mini me and Nathan Lane. The movie is not just a comedy but also a musical, where we see Dr. Evil and Mini-me do a rendition of Hard Knock Life (Jay-Z) it is one of the funniest scenes in the movie. Beyonce Knowles does a suprisingly good in her acting debut. And Mike Myers, Michael Caine are good in it. I would see it again. Very Funny movie.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-31</date>
		<username>Stefan Kahrs</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Funny but disjointed</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is in many ways routine - well-made, with a good joke/time ratio, lots of the required silliness, and even a few moments of inspiration. Some new contributions to the series work better than others (Nigel Powers: good, Goldmember: bad), but by going through such a checklist one by one I make the same mistake the writers made: not thinking about the picture as a whole.As a whole, the film is too disjointed. There are good little tidbits here and there, mostly at the required hilarity level, but the joints squeak and squeal. That is particularly noticeable towards the beginning when we get a few musical numbers too many. Apart from this Burlesque-inspired combination of music and comedy, the disjointness can be blamed on several underdevelopments of plot and characters. The time travel to 1975 was confined to a few references of 1970s culture, the Goldmember character is largely side-lined, and Mini-me's defection deserved more attention.In the end, it's the Blazing Saddles school of comedy, not the more coherent approach of Support Your Local Sheriff.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-31</date>
		<username>TheRedneck2004</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Much better than the second, as good or better than the first</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What a riot. I've enjoyed all of the movies so far, but the second to a much lesser degree. I had mediocre expectations going into Goldmember, and laughed hysterically through the whole thing.There are very few recycled jokes (and they even admit to recycling one of them during the movie, which itself is funny when you see it), and one that (I think) was done better than in The Spy Who Shagged Me. The new humor is great, I love all the Dutch jokes! Anyways, as a movie, this plot makes more sense than Spy, and the characters actually have more to do. Austin, again, isn't the funniest character in the movie. Dr. Evil, Scott, and Mini Me steal the show, with Goldmember runnerup. If you've watched the first two and always wanted Scott to actually DO something, or Mini Me to be an essential character, this is the movie for you. The fight between Fat Bastard and Austin in the Japanese...bath chamber?...is a classic.The Pitfalls: The beginning seems a little forced to me, Spy still has the greatest opening credits, though Goldmember's is still enjoyable.The ending is slightly anti-climactic, but then again, only slightly. I expected Scott to take matters into his own hands at the end, but then he just runs off. And Goldmembers' defeat is pretty quick. But still it's enjoyable.Mixed Feelings: Foxy Cleopatra. Very spunky performance, but she doesn't really do anything. I mean, she's technically "there", but her role is less than the the other two women in the previous movies.Greatest Moments: Dr. Evil's reaction to "the Mole" every time.Mini Me vs. Austin Powers rematch.Definately one of the funniest movies I've ever seen.</fullReview>
	</review>

I hope like hell Mike Meyers makes a fourth installment. I know I'll be there the day it opens. It'll still be better than most anything else that's out there (which "Goldmember" certainly is). 		<shortDescription>Non-stop hilarious</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The only thing I hated about this movie was that it didn't give me any breathing time: I was laughing too hard! Everyone says the jokes are recycled, but it's not true. Only the *type* of jokes are the same, but guess what? WHO CARES?! As long as the jokes are still funny, why do the *format* of the jokes have to be original?People claim only stupid people will think this movie is funny. Well I'm an ivy league graduate doing cancer research, and I consider Mike Meyers a genius for pulling off so many laughs so consistently. If you don't like this movie, you either have no sense of humor or are one of those artsy-types who can't stand anything that resembles anything else.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-31</date>
		<username>Karl Elvis</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Funny, but a deep disappointment.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After the stellar farce of "Spy who shagged me", "Goldmember" feels like a contractual obligation - Myers is phoning it in, doing an indifferent Austin Powers and a pathetic Doctor Evil - dropping the character completely in places, lapsing into his Canadian accent in others. His other characters add nothing - Fat Bastard brings nothing but gross-out, and Goldmember isn't a good or accurate satire of anything, he's just odd. Myers characters are what drive these films, so when he's not on, there's not a lot left.In fact, the only really good performances are from Verne Troyer as Mini-me, and Seth Green as Scott Evil; both tun in performances that are worthy of the previous film. Troyer seems to have a gift for physical comedy beyond just his very small stature.While there are certainly good moments and great gags (the submarine, the opening), much of this file is stale and indifferent rehash. I wanted to like it - I tried hard to like it. But when Ozzy Osborne saying "boobs" is one of the funniest bits in a film, something's missing.This does not even get into the technical film-making, which looked rather low budget, or the editing, which was sloppy. The end result is a film that looks tossed together.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-07-31</date>
		<username>Karl Elvis</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Funny, but a deep disappointment.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After the stellar farce of "Spy who shagged me", "Goldmember" feels like a contractual obligation - Myers is phoning it in, doing an indifferent Austin Powers and a pathetic Doctor Evil - dropping the character completely in places, lapsing into his Canadian accent in others. His other characters add nothing - Fat Bastard brings nothing but gross-out, and Goldmember isn't a good or accurate satire of anything, he's just odd. Myers characters are what drive these films, so when he's not on, there's not a lot left.In fact, the only really good performances are from Verne Troyer as Mini-me, and Seth Green as Scott Evil; both tun in performances that are worthy of the previous film. Troyer seems to have a gift for physical comedy beyond just his very small stature.While there are certainly good moments and great gags (the submarine, the opening), much of this file is stale and indifferent rehash. I wanted to like it - I tried hard to like it. But when Ozzy Osborne saying "boobs" is one of the funniest bits in a film, something's missing.This does not even get into the technical film-making, which looked rather low budget, or the editing, which was sloppy. The end result is a film that looks tossed together.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-31</date>
		<username>xenagaby77</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Uneven But Often Hilarious</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A trippy, almost surreal vision from Mike Myers that is generally engaging but occasionally misfires. The plot involves another ransom demand from Dr. Evil, who threatens to use a "tractor beam" to pull a large meteor toward Earth. The opening sequence, with several superstar cameos, is amusing and wonderful. The rest of the movie is a series of rapid-fire gags; many of them are of the self-parody variety. Goldmember doesn't have much witty dialogue, but his presence is intended to be an absurd homage, (complete with sick personal habits) to the gold-obsessed Auric Goldfinger character. Similarly, Beyonce Knowles as Foxxy Cleopatra is here primarily to emulate Pam Grier's persona from her sassy "blaxpoitation" movies in the 70's. I found these homages to be clever and well done. Beyonce is very sexy and delivered her lines very competently for a 20 year old with no acting experience. One of the failures of the movie is Foxxy does not become a romantic interest during the movie, as Vanessa and Felicity did in the earlier 2 movies. That would have given the movie more soul. The gags are mostly funny, however. The rap by Doctor Evil in prison is terrific. Seth Green's new gambit for his father's love and respect becomes hilarious and he ends the movie on a petulant, defiant note. Mini-Me's "conversion" is also hilarious, especially his new duds as a Powers' convert. However, the fight between Mini-Me and a misconstruing Powers does drag on too long. I'm one of the few who thinks Fat Bastard is funny and I thought he was more funny here than in the last movie. Michael Caine was drolly amusing as Austin's father. I loved Nathan Lane's cameo as a Foxxy liasion. The least amusing scene was Austin's (over)reaction to the "Mole" character. However, the Mole's scene with Dr. Evil was genuinely funny. All in all, this is a fun movie to watch. I recommend it, especially if you can see it with other fans of Myers' absurdist humor. 8/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-30</date>
		<username>doq</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>wow, that was really bad</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was really surprised to see people giving this film high marks... I did like the first two and honestly didnt expect much from this one... it delivered about as expected, but thats not really a good thing.There were some solid scenes, the opening for example, the subtitle stuff, etc. But I felt the film had absolutely no flow whatsoever.It just feels like the creators took a sheet of paper, wrote down every funny idea they've ever had, and then forced them into the movie with no explanation or plot whatsoever.I understand its a light hearted comedy, but even watching it as such was painful... I kept hoping it would end so I could do something else.All in all, matinee is a stretch, certainly good as a rental, and still funny, i suppose.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Thank god I didn't pay to see it...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, this is what free movie tickets are made for. The first Austin Powers was hilarious. A gem of a movie from that year. The second Austin Powers was more disgusting than it was funny. For the third one they took out the most sickening humor from the second one, but then forgot to add the jokes!There are, really, perhaps 3 funny scenes (and those are recycled from the first two movies, only in much shorter form) in the entire movie... Then you have the other hour... Boring, un-funny, I mean didn't they have a clue when Mini-Me kept falling asleep during the exposition in the beginning?You have Fred Savage as the Mole, a hilarious character that feels like it's building to go somewhere but never quite arrives. You have the cameos from Tom Cruise, Steven Spielberg and John Travolta that are more distracting than they are funny.Really the only new and funny thing in the entire movie is the transition of Scott Evil from bored teen rebel to twisted Evil Genius.Give this one a pass, don't even rent it. It's not worth your time.- Jordan</fullReview>

		<date>2002-07-30</date>
		<username>dinger54</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>the set is complete</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have really enjoyed the first two Austin movies and this one completed the series. I think there are 3 things you have to keep in mind when seeing this movie.One-it is hard to still make people laugh the third time around. People expected a lot from this movie and I think Mike Myers did a good job.Two-don't take this movie too seriously. I have read comments where people are trying to find the inner themes and meanings behind this movie-they do not exist. It is an armpit-joke type movie and you must leave it at that.Three-the audience you see it with will depend on how well you enjoy this flick. I realize it really is out of your hands what the crowd is like, but both times i went to it-the crowd really wanted to laugh, so every five seconds someone was busting a nut. It is even better when there is that one guy in the crowd who has that distinct laugh that is going bonkers throughout the whole movie-those people are the bestIf you liked the first two Austin Powers movies-go see the third. You won't be let down. My personal opinion is that the second movie was the best, but you be your own judge. For those of you who bash this movie and have the stupidity to write about it-hey there were two before this one, so what made you think this movie would be any different-did someone put a gun to your head and make you pay 7 bucks to see it-i doubt it. If you go there wanting to laugh and have a good time-your in for a real treat.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-30</date>
		<username>Clanallan</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Dry and tired, though the shagging's not...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It may be safe to say that any of the Mike Myers' Austin Powers films are sure to make you laugh, as all of them have for me. Maybe that is why we all rushed out to see the third installment, Austin Powers in Goldmember, out of commitment and curiosity. However, a part of me says you can still watch the first two and get the same banter you will from the third one. Don't get me wrong, there is plenty original material in Goldmember, some really funny jokes and the ever popular Dr.Evil - MiniMe Duet, but the series grows tired, and even dry. I already knew Austin Powers can dance to make girls heads explode, I knew Dr. Evil likes to ask for obnoxious sums of money, and I knew Fat Bastard is slightly uncouth. These things are repeated, not subliminally, but instead there to smack you in the face. Ok fine, touch base with the preceding films. Now on to good stuff, the new stuff. There were some scenes alone that definitely made this film worth seeing, and worth laughing. One being the urine sample scene, conspicuously as silhouettes on a curtain, and the subtitles scene. New additions such as the gaseous Evil Submarine and the energetic Beyonce Knowles refresh the film, reminding the audience of Myers' creativeness. If you're a Powers fan, you've already seen the movie, if you're teetering on the edge, make sure you haven't seen the first two movies in a while.</fullReview>
	</review>
