	<review>
		<date>2002-07-27</date>
		<username>w00f</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>A Few Chuckles, but Mediocre</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I loved the first couple of Austin Powers movies, and this one wasn't terrible either, but there was nothing outstanding about it. It recycled a lot of material from the first two Powers flicks in a self-conscious way. It's getting harder to tell whether Mike Meyers is parodying film clichés or falling into them himself. This one contained even more poo-poo and pee-pee jokes than the first couple, to the point that it got tiring 3/4 of the way into the movie.The accent Meyers chose for the title character got very annoying a few minutes after the first time he spoke. Meyers has a lot of talent for this sort of thing, but Goldmember's accent came across as contrived and a bit stiff, like Meyers was trying too hard.Michael Caine is a lot of fun as Austin Power's father, Nigel Powers. It was obvious from his performance that Caine was having a very good time on the set. The Cockney "private conversation" between Caine and Meyers is one of the high points of the movie.Personally, I think this series is getting tired. Meyers should consider moving onto a fresh project instead of milking the Austin Powers character for all he's worth. The ending of Goldmember makes it abundantly clear, however, that there's going to be another sequel. I don't know if that's such a good idea... I felt after seeing this one, while I did have a few laughs, that Meyers is getting close to taking the easy way out as far as coming up with new material. His time would be better spent, I think, going in a new direction. Maybe its time for a Deiter movie?</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-27</date>
		<username>kellyadmirer</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Cameos the best part</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I chuckled a few times. For a comedy, I should have been laughing a lot more. Some of the jokes were more clever than humorous, more droll than amusing. Some fellow behind me actually groaned at a punny use of the line "He's not heavy, he's my brother." Many references like that seemed aimed at an older audience than the rest of the film, which makes me think the series is starting to lose focus and perhaps should die a merciful death with this film.The only parts of the film that elicited hearty audience reactions (I saw it on the day it came out, theater about 2/3 full) were the cameos. Some of them really surprised me, and to tell you the truth, the film-within-a-film that opens the movie was a whole lot more entertaining than the real film. The stars they got to make cameos make appearances at both the beginning and end of the film, wearing out the gimmick a bit, but that is par for the course these days in comedies - if something works once, repeat it at least once and preferably several times to milk it for all it is worth.Beyonce Knowles does a fabulous acting job for a singer and was the best part of the film. Michael Caine slowed things down every time he appeared, and some of his scenes were completely over-written and could have been dispensed with or completed in half the time. Robert Wagner would have been good if Meyers had given him anything to do, but mainly he sits around and looks pained. Seth Green looks like he is going through a career crisis, I hope he makes it.This installment shows all the signs of a series past its prime. It is obsessively self-referential, there are huge props that probably cost a pretty penny to create, and the precise same gags used in the previous installments are done again, but in an exaggerated way, exactly in the style of Meyer's launching pad, Saturday Night Live. I'm not sure why Meyers feels the need to play all the key parts himself, but he is no Peter Sellers and the gimmick wears thin in a hurry (he should have stopped at just Austin and Dr. Evil, less is more here).It was mildly entertaining, but not memorable. If they try to flog this dying horse for another round, it will probably stink, like Superman IV or the last Jaws installments. Probably a good rental on dvd, but not worth going out of your way to see in the theater.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Spawn Devil</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>

		<date>2002-07-27</date>
		<username>kismit</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Easily the worst of the three Powers movies.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It seems the Austin Powers saga will end, thankfully with this third installment. The humour is the same but where it came in a steady stream in the first two films it trickles in this one. The cameos in the opening credits are the high point and then it's slowly down hill as the film is not a story but a series of setups for gags that are a little too repetitive. You would be more entertained renting Spy Who Shagged me then watching this dog.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-07-27</date>
		<username>Pelrad</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>From Silver to Gold: The Strongest Entry in the Series</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have seen a lot of movies in the cinema over the years. This one had the audience laughing harder and more often than any other movie I've seen in history. Much better written the the previous two Austin Powers movies, much more energetic, with never a dull moment, with a clever opening and a surprise ending, this really confirms the brilliant comedic mind of Mike Myers. Just awesome.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-27</date>
		<username>Jerry Smith</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Hilarious, but the weak link in the trilogy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>(There could possibly be spoilers, so read at your own risk. And if they are spoilers, they're not big)This movie was hilarious, no doubt saying that. But it is definitely the worst of the three. It's not as fresh as the first, or as original of jokes as the second, but it still has its great moments (The cameos were hysterical). Although some cameos didn't deliver anything but stupidity. Can somebody answer me, what the hell was Britney Spears and the Osbournes doing there?!? I didn't hear a single laugh out of anyone in the audience when those two cameos arrived. Here are my pros and cons of the movie:Pros: 1. Once again, the hilarious cameos. I will only say that Danny DeVito's was hysterical. 2. Fat Bastard (who, surprisingly, isn't there long enough)Minime, and Dr. Evil steal every scene they are in.Cons: 1. Once again, the useless cameos. 2. Goldmember, was not funny whatsoever besides his strange dutch accent. He was there to gross you out with his skin problem. 3. Foxxy Cleopatra was unfunny also and is just there to wear cleavage (I didn't mind but she was the worst girl of the three). 4. Ridiculous and sometimes, just stupid, bathroom jokes. 5. They steal many of the past two movies jokes and put them in this one, which was aggravating.6. The absence of Heather Graham's character wasn't a good thing. 7. Michael Caine's character was a little bit aggravating but had many funny jokes. 8. Last but not least, the worthless ending. I was so anticipating the ending to see what happens, but it ends up stupid.So as you can see there are many more cons than pros but I will still recommend you to see it, but only if you like bathroom jokes, which I don't. Rating 7 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-27</date>
		<username>mylo57</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Not impressed.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let me start off by saying that I was greatly disappointed with "Austin Powers in Goldmember." We waited 2 hours to see it the night it came out, and I was mad to discover that it turned grossly corney after the first 10 minutes. Granted, I did laugh out loud maybe 3 or 4 times through the rest of the movie, however the third installment of this series is no where near the witticism of the first two. There were nothing but stupid cliches and played out jokes in this movie. Foxy Cleopatra's character was completely underdeveloped. One thing that made the first two movies great was the dynamic relationship between Austin and his leading lady, and there is none of this in Goldmember.I suppose my biggest qualm with this movie was that the editing was HORRIBLE. It was so ridiculously choppy, it seemed like half of the plot must have been cut out. I mean, there were no transitions between scenes what so ever. And where the hell did Britney Spears come from?Finally, why the heck is this movie called "Goldmember" in the first place? The Goldmember character is barely even in it, and he is so not funny it's embarrassing to watch.Ok, so my overall rating for this movie is a D+, only because the Tom Cruise bit was hilarious.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-27</date>
		<username>Cbrizen</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>The 1st Austin Powers movie was great, the 2nd was better, but the 3rd one is the best!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Last night I went to see "Goldmember", the newest installment in the hilarious Austin Powers movies. The theater was packed and almost every seat was filled. After the opening scene, everyone in the theater was just dying in their seats. I was, in fact, also. "Goldmember" is by far the funniest of the 3 Austin Powers movies! There are some very funny celebrity cameos, but the Osbournes really just need to go away. The sight gags from the first 2 films are back, and better than ever! The character Goldmember was very funny, and Fat B*****d is more hilarious in this one, but way more disgusting. It was also very funny how Austin reacted to the mole on, well The Mole. And of course Austin and Dr. Evil are very funny. Don't forget Mini-Me! Anyone who says this is the worst film of the Austin Powers movies has no sense of humor. I think a lot of people would agree because everyone in the theater was laughing so hard. And how could you not like a movie that is making fun of Jay-Z?</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-27</date>
		<username>lolxors</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Overrated repeat</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I really didn't know what to expect from this 3rd installment of the Austin Powers franchise. I did expect the line on opening night to be extremely long. Thankfully the wait time I spent was only 1 hr and twenty minutes because I would have killed myself otherwise. I really savored the opening credits for it is something that was completely unexpected. After the opening I had carried over high hopes that the movie be better than watching clothes spin in a dryer...I lost my anticipation as soon as I saw the same "shh" joke from the previous two Austins. Even though most of the jokes were recycled, there were a few scenes that made me open up and blast my drink downward. The storyline seemed to have come from one of those websites that every loser in the world can add a line to the story, twists and stupidity ensues surprises and bad accents. If you liked Austin before, you might like this movie as the trilogy completes, but if you never did like the series, do not waste your time/money on this overrated repeat. Just remember, you don't have to leave the theater right away, go to another one to get your money's worth, since Goldmember is not worth the eight dollars you paid. Popcorn?</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-27</date>
		<username>John Cosgrove</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Just doing it for the money now</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Thankfully, I went to a bargain afternoon show and didn't have to pay full price to see this fetid piece of dog crap. Ozzy Osbourne said it best in the film when he noted that the breast joke was simply a repeat of bits we've seen in the other 2 films. When not ripping themselves off, the filmmakers apparently thought it would be funny if Dr. Evil mumbles incoherently, or takes one in the groin or Mini-Me runs into a wall. The only ones in the theater laughing were the 10 year olds this material was apparently aimed at. I can honestly say I did not laugh once, the first time this has happened since the 80's debacle Howard the Duck. I went to the film with great apprehension, since Austin II was such a major letdown after the first, cult classic film. Seems there's a law of diminishing returns applied to this series. I'm just disappointed that the IMDB won't let me rate lower than 1, so I'll do it here: 0/10.</fullReview>
	</review>

If you liked Austin before, you might like this movie as the trilogy completes, but if you never did like the series, do not waste your time/money on this overrated repeat. 		<fullReview>Whereas AP II was surprisingly even more ingenious and funnier than the first, AP III was good for only a few chuckles in the opening scene. None of the edgy hipness of the first two made it to this one. Oh well.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-27</date>
		<username>smartstrigz</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>3rd in Series, 3rd in Quality</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First of all, let me say that I really did enjoy this movie. However, it does not live up to the other Austin Powers movies in the trilogy.Working at a movie theater, I had heard all day Friday from people exiting the theater that it was the best Austin Powers film yet, it provided endless laughs, and especially the opening scene was amazing. I was greatly anticipating our private employee showing late that night, but what I saw instead somewhat disappointed me.Although Mike Meyers does a great job as usual in playing multiple characters, most of the jokes and plot was recycled from the first two movies. The writers obviously tried to continue on from the best jokes from the 2nd movie, but they just aren't funny this time around. There was such a lack of new content in this movie that it made the movie a little boring about 3/4 of the way through the movie. Also, unlike the 2nd movie (The Spy who Shagged Me) which provided almost non-stop laughter, this one has much more down-time in which you have to wait for the comedic moments. Thats not a big deal if what you wait for is worth it, but these comedic moments are definitely not worth the wait. Sure, there were the few times when the audience all instantly roared in laughter, but those times were seldom.One of my biggest problems with this movie is not the recycled content, it is instead the overall theme of the movie: Goldmember. I have never seen a movie named after a character with such a minor part in the movie. Goldmember does play a part in a few of the funnier parts of the movie, especially when Dr. Evil is having a little language/accent communication problem. Other than that though, hes hardly even around.Another drawback of the movie is the amount of other famous people in the movie. Britney Spears makes a brief appearance, but has absolutely nothing to do with the plot. She is simply in the movie to be in the movie. There are plenty of other brief star appearances, but I don't want to go into those because some people consider it extremely funny and I don't want to ruin it for you. But...There is definitely one star that did deserve to be in that movie, and that is Beyonce Knowles. I thought she was going to be just like all the other stars in it, playing a meaningless character and just in the movie for publicity, however she played her part to absolute perfection. She was definitely the star of this movie, every time she was on screen you could count on some excellent acting and funny moments.Overall, the movie isn't bad, it just has a lot of drawbacks that will keep many movie-goers a little disappointed with the third installment of the series. The series, which constantly pokes fun at other movies, now seems to be poking fun at itself at times, but yet the writers did set it up for another sequel... however they also set it up to end the series if thats what they want to do. Go see Goldmember, you'll enjoy it, but be slightly disappointed.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<shortDescription>The best in the series! DROP DEAD FUNNY!</shortDescription>

And the latest one, Austin Powers in Goldmember, is the best yet! The returning cast of Mike Myers, now playing four roles, along with Seth Green, Robert Wagner, Verne Troyer, and Mindy Sterling are perfect! With all the junk movies out there that are supposed to be "real movies", I at least had some fun watching this one. Everyone was funny and I liked all of the cameos. So if you like Austin Powers, don't listen to all of those evil reviews and go have some fun baby.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Didn't Strike Gold</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film has some clever parodies, some witty dialogue, and some great cameos. Problem is...there is only some. In between these are infernal sequences composed of lengthy and purile concepts that are unfit fodder for swine. It is a true shame, the concept is good, and there is potential here. The cast has amazing talents such as Robert Wagner, Michael York, and Michael Caine. The characters' dialogue is not worked to it's fullest potential. I only wish that more time had been spent on writing, rather than pointless unintelligible jokes and funny faces.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-26</date>
		<username>Brad A. (bradmagic)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Goldmember is fine, not bad, not beautiful.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In the various reviews I've read about Goldmember I see pure fans gulping down the small idiosyncrasies and other foibles in the story.This movie is good.Indeed it isn't as creative, or "new" as the first two films; however, it has the creative and trademarked comedy that can only be found in a film by Mike Myers.Some scatological, some intellectual, other things just Monty Python...the comedy in this film appears to be duplicates of "good" stuff from the first two.The good stuff: The story flows well. It moves at a pace that keeps one awake and interested. There are a number of jokes that were so humorous I stopped breathing. The characters, and the actors behind them, all did very well.The Not-So-Good stuff: Again, sometimes the jokes are just repeats. But, there's nothing wrong with them. I LOVE AUSTIN POWER JOKES, seeing repeats of the same jokes is great. There could have been some more "new" things, but the reuse of older ideas didn't bother me.That's all the bad things I have to say!In general, this is a very good movie. I sat in a nicely sized audience, and have never heard people laugh so hard. Why do some of these other reviewers have to be so harsh to the film?This movie is good.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-26</date>
		<username>mikeslant</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Some recycled jokes, bet close to on par with Spy Who...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was able to catch a sneak preview of Goldmember and, overall, I liked what I saw. I didn't really know how funny this would be because something the Powers series was becoming known for with the second installment: Recycled jokes. Yes, Goldmember has some recycled jokes, plenty of them, but at least the film identifies this in the Osbournes scene. I expected the characters to be more tired than in the previous installment, and indeed they were. Fans of the series will probably still enjoy some of the moments with Scott, Mini-Me, Fat Bastard, etc. The story has it's crazy take over the world idea, but it still could have remembered this series started as a Bond-series spoof. Dr. Evil is more insane and, while a bit tired, is still rather funny, especially the Silence of the Lambs spoof when Mini-Me and Evil go to prison. It has a a "friggin" funny take on the song 'Hard Noc Life' that will no doubt be dated sooner rather than later. The new character Goldmember wasn't too funny, pretty much falls flat. No matter what, Myers has to be given props for playing 4 different characters, but at the same time 4 is maybe one too many....New female love interest Foxxy Cleopatra was OK at best, certainly nothing great and I found both Vanessa and Felicity to be better. Michael Caine is a different story though, he was funny and brought some freshness with his character. The only thing I didn't like that much was the ending, too "tie everything up neat and happy," though I enjoy what happens to the character of Scott. Getting a bit dated and stale, but still an entry into the series a bit behind the second. I'd say Myers needs to fresh up the franchise though if they continue with a fourth one. And yes, the cameos are hilarious...</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-07-26</date>
		<username>Robert Prince (r.prince@verizon.net)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Low brow for sure, but we hardly stopped laughing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I see that Austin Powers is getting very mixed reviews, both from the pros and IMDB users, and be assured that it will not be joining Some Like It Hot and Tootsie as one of the funniest and intelligent movies of all time. Perhaps it suffers a bit from a wee too much scatology. And the plot is the barest wisp of a framework to hold the movie together. It's really just a series of gags and sketches.Nevertheless, I recommend this movie for the simplest of reasons: The audience I saw this with, including me, hardly stopped laughing throughout. A few of the gags are so gross they'll make you wince, and a few are carryovers from the first two Austin Powers films, but on the whole the movie is one funny, creative bit after another. And the many surprise cameos are a hoot.Kudos too for Beyoncé Knowles for a funny and charming turn as Foxy Cleopatra. While not the most complex female lead in film history, she fills the limited demands of the role nicely.These days, a film that does nothing more than keep me laughing for an hour and a half will get my vote every time.8 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-26</date>
		<username>zeitlin-2</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>90 Minutes of mini-skits</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I am a fan of the first two Austin Powers movies. Unfortunately, I will not be a fan of the third. While the movie does have it's moments, too much time was spent on the clever opening and not the movie itself. The movie is comprised of skits strung together by a very loose storyline. To my wife and I, it seems that much of this material was stuff left behind, not good enough for the first two movies. The other 'skits' were simply rehashing of old jokes. It further seemed Mike Meyers was a) consumed with his own popularity of the first two movies and b) just sent this one in. The jokes, while raunchy in the first two but had purpose, simply were attempts to gross the audience out or go for the cheap thrill. I was very disappointed in this movie. It didn't live up the expectations, based on the brillance of the first two. I am sure I will be in the minority in my opinion, but watch closely and you will see what I saw.</fullReview>
	</review>

Just don't be looking for any of the comic revelations of the previous Mike Meyers movies, actually this does feel like Wayne's World 2 (but not as good!!), with it's repetitions from the other movies. 		<date>2002-07-26</date>
		<username>Code_Green</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Austin Powers Does It Again!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just saw "Austin Powers in Goldmember" so since it's fresh in my mind, I'll make my comment on it. I give it 8 stars out of 10. It was very funny, it had a few references to the '70s, and not so much the '60s like the first two movies. Dr. Evil finally gets captured and it happens just when he's revealing his latest plot which is to go to 1975 to meet Goldmember, who has invented a successful tracking beam. He code names the plan, "Preparation H". They will use the tracking beam to bring a meteor to Earth to flood the planet. Soon after, Austin's father Nigel Powers is kidnapped and he finds out from Dr. Evil that he must go back to '75 to find Goldmember, who has Nigel. While there he meets his old flame Foxxy Cleopatra who is a detective. They both go back to 2002 after Goldmember goes to 2002 with Nigel and soon they are involved with Goldmember and Dr. Evil's newest plot. They recycled a few jokes from the first two movies like the joke with Austin being behind a sheet with Felicity and it seemed like she was pulling things out of his ass. They also (once again) recycled the joke where Dr. Evil asks the government for $1,000,000. It was very good. Beyonc?'s performance was exceptional and Mike Myers once again succeeded in making a great movie. The cameos were great. Britney Spears, Gwyneth Paltrow, Tom Cruise, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito, Katie Couric, the Ozzbournes, the list goes on. The only complaint I have is that they never explained what had happened to Felicity Shagwell. I could understand if maybe Heather Graham didn't want to be in the movie, but still, they could've at least given a brief explanation to what happened to her within the movie. Even so, I highly anticipate seeing this again, and I will definintely get it when it comes to video. Also, I do hope that they make an Austin Powers 4.</fullReview>
	</review>

They recycled a few jokes from the first two movies like the joke with Austin being behind a sheet with Felicity and it seemed like she was pulling things out of his ass. They also (once again) recycled the joke where Dr. Evil asks the government for $1,000,000. It was very good. Beyonc?'s performance was exceptional and Mike Myers once again succeeded in making a great movie. The cameos were great. Britney Spears, Gwyneth Paltrow, Tom Cruise, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito, Katie Couric, the Ozzbournes, the list goes on. The only complaint I have is that they never explained what had happened to Felicity Shagwell. I could understand if maybe Heather Graham didn't want to be in the movie, but still, they could've at least given a brief explanation to what happened to her within the movie. Even so, I highly anticipate seeing this again, and I will definintely get it when it comes to video. Also, I do hope that they make an Austin Powers 4.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-26</date>
		<username>Brad A. (bradmagic)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Goldmember is fine, not bad, not beautiful.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In the various reviews I've read about Goldmember I see pure fans gulping down the small idiosyncrasies and other foibles in the story.This movie is good.Indeed it isn't as creative, or "new" as the first two films; however, it has the creative and trademarked comedy that can only be found in a film by Mike Myers.Some scatological, some intellectual, other things just Monty Python...the comedy in this film appears to be duplicates of "good" stuff from the first two.The good stuff: The story flows well. It moves at a pace that keeps one awake and interested. There are a number of jokes that were so humorous I stopped breathing. The characters, and the actors behind them, all did very well.The Not-So-Good stuff: Again, sometimes the jokes are just repeats. But, there's nothing wrong with them. I LOVE AUSTIN POWER JOKES, seeing repeats of the same jokes is great. There could have been some more "new" things, but the reuse of older ideas didn't bother me.That's all the bad things I have to say!In general, this is a very good movie. I sat in a nicely sized audience, and have never heard people laugh so hard. Why do some of these other reviewers have to be so harsh to the film?This movie is good.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-26</date>
		<username>mikeslant</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Some recycled jokes, bet close to on par with Spy Who...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was able to catch a sneak preview of Goldmember and, overall, I liked what I saw. I didn't really know how funny this would be because something the Powers series was becoming known for with the second installment: Recycled jokes. Yes, Goldmember has some recycled jokes, plenty of them, but at least the film identifies this in the Osbournes scene. I expected the characters to be more tired than in the previous installment, and indeed they were. Fans of the series will probably still enjoy some of the moments with Scott, Mini-Me, Fat Bastard, etc. The story has it's crazy take over the world idea, but it still could have remembered this series started as a Bond-series spoof. Dr. Evil is more insane and, while a bit tired, is still rather funny, especially the Silence of the Lambs spoof when Mini-Me and Evil go to prison. It has a a "friggin" funny take on the song 'Hard Noc Life' that will no doubt be dated sooner rather than later. The new character Goldmember wasn't too funny, pretty much falls flat. No matter what, Myers has to be given props for playing 4 different characters, but at the same time 4 is maybe one too many....New female love interest Foxxy Cleopatra was OK at best, certainly nothing great and I found both Vanessa and Felicity to be better. Michael Caine is a different story though, he was funny and brought some freshness with his character. The only thing I didn't like that much was the ending, too "tie everything up neat and happy," though I enjoy what happens to the character of Scott. Getting a bit dated and stale, but still an entry into the series a bit behind the second. I'd say Myers needs to fresh up the franchise though if they continue with a fourth one. And yes, the cameos are hilarious...</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

The best part was when they showed them as young students and Evan Farmer was there as young Number 2. You may remember him from the best movie ever made, 2GETHER, he played Jerry. 	<review>
		<date>2002-07-26</date>
		<username>Robert Prince (r.prince@verizon.net)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Low brow for sure, but we hardly stopped laughing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I see that Austin Powers is getting very mixed reviews, both from the pros and IMDB users, and be assured that it will not be joining Some Like It Hot and Tootsie as one of the funniest and intelligent movies of all time. Perhaps it suffers a bit from a wee too much scatology. And the plot is the barest wisp of a framework to hold the movie together. It's really just a series of gags and sketches.Nevertheless, I recommend this movie for the simplest of reasons: The audience I saw this with, including me, hardly stopped laughing throughout. A few of the gags are so gross they'll make you wince, and a few are carryovers from the first two Austin Powers films, but on the whole the movie is one funny, creative bit after another. And the many surprise cameos are a hoot.Kudos too for Beyoncé Knowles for a funny and charming turn as Foxy Cleopatra. While not the most complex female lead in film history, she fills the limited demands of the role nicely.These days, a film that does nothing more than keep me laughing for an hour and a half will get my vote every time.8 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-07-26</date>
		<username>joliegrrl</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wait for the DVD</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went into this film with the highest of hopes. Having seen the first two installments, and absolutely loving them, I couldn't wait to see Goldmember. Perhaps I should have hesitated a bit. After an incredible cameo filled opening, the film slips into gross-out humor and non-existant plotline. There are the usual suspects:Dr. Evil, Fat Bastard, Mini-Me, Frau Farbissina, and of course Austin, and they deliver, but their "act" seems old and predictable. The addition of Michael Caine could've added a burst of freshness, but he is underused, and just ends up being a poor parody of himself. Beyonce Knowles as Foxxy Cleopatra is a combination of every Blaxpoitation movie out there, but she is little more than fodder for the eye, and her acting talent(if there is any)does not get the opportunity to emerge. Seth Green was an unlikely standout as Dr. Evil's son Scott. His transformation to "evil" is one of the highpoints of the movie. Also, look for a school-years flashback of Austin and Dr. Evil that had me in stitches, and in awe of the young men portraying them. These high points were few and far between. This is not to say that "Austin Powers in Goldmember" didn't make me laugh, it just didn't make continuously laugh. In this franchise, the third time really isn't the charm. My advice is to save your hard earned cash, and wait for the DVD, which will probably have all sorts of extras, which will actually make you feel like you got your money's worth, which unfortunately I did not.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-26</date>
		<username>cgw-3</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Third time's a charm, baby!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>He's back, baby. It's the shagadelic third installment in the spy series. This time, Austin Powers (Mike Myers) must save the day, again, when his arch-nemesis Dr. Evil (Mike Myers) threatens to flood the earth by using a laser beam to control the earth's satellite. In order to stop him, Austin must travel back to 1975 and rescue his father Nigel Powers (Michael Caine) from Dr. Evil's newest henchman, Goldmember (Mike Myers, again!) and form an alliance with ex-girlfriend Foxxy Cleopatra (Beyoncé Knowles), then travel back to 2002 to stop Goldmember, Dr. Evil, and the rest of his infamous gang of henchmen.Even though this installment is the funniest of the three (the first 10 to 15 minutes of the movie is a riotous hoot with cameos galore), Goldmember is the weakest link of the series. With his testicles made of gold and having a weird attribute of eating his peeled skin, it almost makes you sick to your stomach in some scenes. The other let down of the movie, Heather Graham had a cameo appearance as Felicity Shagwell and all her scenes ended up on the cutting room floor. Oh, well. The revelation is unexpected (except to those who saw the first two movies), and the ending leaves the door open for a fourth Austin Powers adventure. Funniest moments are the first 15 minutes of the movie, the clever &amp; witty names of female characters (and everybody who thought `Fook Yu' was a bad word will now be grateful to say in front of parents. Don't worry, they won't get it until DVD release), Dr. Evil's version of a Jay-Z rap song, Dr. Evil's new lair, the satellite (which is reminiscent of number two's funniest moments), the battle between Austin and Fat Bastard (Michael Myers from those `Halloween' slasher films), and Fred Savage as The Mole. After the movie, you'll wonder: Which direction will AP4 take if they decide to make it? (Trust me, you'll be asking yourself this mind-boggling question.) Yeah, baby!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-25</date>
		<username>WilliamSG</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Oh so tired..</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>**Very minor spoilers**The first was good. The second was still good. The third...oh so bad. The jokes are tired. Even the actors themselves look tired. The best part of the movie was the opening two minutes. After that, it all went downhill. Britney Spears's cameo however was just shameless and I'm glad her head exploded a short time after she appears. Midway through the first half you can't wait for it to be over. Yes, there were a few good jokes, but the movie as a whole felt so much more crude than the original two that I actually cringed in parts. Mini-me though does steal the show completely, although I do feel a tinge of guilt for laughing at a midget getting beaten up every two seconds. Michael Caine also proves he's past his acting prime and I'm honestly surprised he picked such a terrible part to play.Anyway, I'll stop right there. Don't go in expecting anything near as 'good' as the first two. This is pure, unadulterated and crude Hollywood.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-25</date>
		<username>giancarlorocks</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>A dismal third attempt at recreating a shagadelic atmosphere...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The best joke in the latest Austin Powers Film comes at the very end when our perrenial villain, Fat Bastard, compares his new look to a women's organ.The third and seemingly last of the Austin Powers films (we will get to that later); Austin Powers in Goldmember, is a disappointing finale if the trilogy does come to an end. This movie is susceptible to what I like to call, 'bowtie endings' in which all the characters are happy, everything falls into place and the masses are pleased with no clear cut solution. Pity, just when I thought the film would bring closure to a great little idea, it falters at a tremendous rate. This being said, please allow me the admittance of describing the feeling for such harsh opening remarks for the third installment of a once venerable franchise. The first Austin Powers film was a little gem. That film literally came out of nowhere and gained its' following on video cassette after a paltry box office. Upon the sequel, the same feel and excitement was elevated after the creative team knew they had to come up something fresh, and they did. For those who follow the films, the tone was set in the second film after a great opening sequence displayed the many abuses the male genitalia can undergo. In the third installment, all the energy runs dry after a hilarious cameo packed action sequence sets the running gag for the 'film within a film' concept. Once we are pleasantly surprised by whom Mike Myers and the rest of the team can assemble for cameo appearances, we are thwarted into vintage Austin Powers territory as the musical introductory sequence occurs. Unfortunately, not all the cameos in the world could save a deplorable and uncreative musical sequence that sets the tone for a heavily choreographed, mildly funny film that solemnly brings closure to the franchise.Mike Myers returns as the heroic Austin Powers, he also returns as the villainous Dr. Evil and the evil henchman Fat Bastard. Amidst all the characters, the creators have decided to throw in another character who is supposed to be from Holland, yet has a freakishly accent reminiscent of New Jersey. The aptly named Goldmember has an affinity for all things gold, and he is supposed to be the driving force behind the evil schemes, yet his character is completetly futile in terms of plot development and those who saw the film, know there isn't even any closure to this character. The question arises - Will there be another Austin Powers film? If it is as recycled as this film was, many will take a pass at it. Some may be asking by this point, why so harsh? It is very simple. Avid fans who have come to know and love the immortal Austin Powers character know the man behind the character; Mike Myers, is a very talented and creative man. Insiders have always claimed many of the intuitive ideas were spawned from Myers and his thorough involvement within the script contributed to the success of the two films. Alas, this cannot be said for the third As aforementioned, from the musical introductory sequence, a morbid feeling came rushing over me as if to say, 'have they already used up all their ideas?'. Yes they have. Director Jay Roach (Meet the Parents, Austin Powers) returns to helm the third installment in what proves to be a disappointing foray into comedy. Roach tries his best at simply running the camera as many of the skits seem to be strictly improvised grounded in about a couple of sentences of script. The key word is skit. This film lacks cohesiveness due to a complete omission of plot. The film mentions something about kidnapping Austin Powers' father (Sir Micheal Caine) and having Goldmember destroy the world. The gags have all been done before and this time, the audience is laughing at recycled elements from the first two films thrown into a pot. This film is like a best of gag reel and amalgamates all the best elements of the first two films and brings them together. It is simply a running skit of gags that in terms of story, do not contribute to one another. Remember the shadow scene from the second film, it is here. Remember the rivalry between Dr. Evil and his son Scott, it is here too. Remember the sequence where they get around saying a graphic word by alluding to it by spotting things in the sky (a la 'Hot Dog' skit in the second film), it is here also.Spunk and creativity are lacking as the film takes on an uncomfortable tone of dismal classiness. The first two were funny, raunchy and wholesome films. This film will guarantee you many laughs, but when the film is over, one will be asking themselves what they were laughing about. It is that exact mindlessness that works against the film. So many times there were scenes that did not elicit laughs from the audience, yet they were still included in the final cut. A lot of little 'bits' in the film did not work, it seemed like a bad high school variety show at some points, but they were still in the film. It is inexplicable when there are uncomfortable pauses within in a comedy, something is incorrect. Adding to the demise of the film is Beyonce Knowles. A singer who makes her acting debut as Foxxy Cleopatra. A Hybrid of Shaft and Jackie Brown all rolled into one. Her character is endlessly annoying and is simply present to prompt awareness about Austin's biracial preferences. In any event, the film will elicit many laughs merely due to the immaturity of the jokes and the recycled cliches brought together. Will it leave the viewer with a dire need to watch it again as in the first two films, sadly no. This time, Austin is not shagadelic.Giancarlo's Rating: **</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-25</date>
		<username>yipching</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Very different - yet the same. Grander, funnier than ever...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I possess the immature sense of humor that makes the Austin Power series the ultimate of comedies for my taste. Right along with Ace Ventura, these movies are about the only films that actually make me laugh out loud. AP3 is different, with the hilarious fake opening, yet takes what was funny about the previous movie and rehashes it into something funnier. There are too many hilarious moments to describe them individually, but I will say there are many surprise cameos. It's a leg humping, mojo blasting, shagadelic romp that shouldn't leave you disappointed.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<fullReview>This film is just as funny as the first two, but it doesn't really distinguish itself from the other two either. Lets just put it this way, they better not try to make a fourth one. See for yourself. It's good for some laughs and great cameos.</fullReview>
	</review>

The biggest problem is that I was expecting more, and expecting that the laughter would be constant. It was not, but still overall this is an excellent film.</fullReview>

It was funny and the movie was good but it was not as good as the previous two movies. The opening was well done and very funny. Tons of Cameos. Music is good. The ending was disappointing - very unlike the previous two. 	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-25</date>
		<username>giancarlorocks</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>A dismal third attempt at recreating a shagadelic atmosphere...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The best joke in the latest Austin Powers Film comes at the very end when our perrenial villain, Fat Bastard, compares his new look to a women's organ.The third and seemingly last of the Austin Powers films (we will get to that later); Austin Powers in Goldmember, is a disappointing finale if the trilogy does come to an end. This movie is susceptible to what I like to call, 'bowtie endings' in which all the characters are happy, everything falls into place and the masses are pleased with no clear cut solution. Pity, just when I thought the film would bring closure to a great little idea, it falters at a tremendous rate. This being said, please allow me the admittance of describing the feeling for such harsh opening remarks for the third installment of a once venerable franchise. The first Austin Powers film was a little gem. That film literally came out of nowhere and gained its' following on video cassette after a paltry box office. Upon the sequel, the same feel and excitement was elevated after the creative team knew they had to come up something fresh, and they did. For those who follow the films, the tone was set in the second film after a great opening sequence displayed the many abuses the male genitalia can undergo. In the third installment, all the energy runs dry after a hilarious cameo packed action sequence sets the running gag for the 'film within a film' concept. Once we are pleasantly surprised by whom Mike Myers and the rest of the team can assemble for cameo appearances, we are thwarted into vintage Austin Powers territory as the musical introductory sequence occurs. Unfortunately, not all the cameos in the world could save a deplorable and uncreative musical sequence that sets the tone for a heavily choreographed, mildly funny film that solemnly brings closure to the franchise.Mike Myers returns as the heroic Austin Powers, he also returns as the villainous Dr. Evil and the evil henchman Fat Bastard. Amidst all the characters, the creators have decided to throw in another character who is supposed to be from Holland, yet has a freakishly accent reminiscent of New Jersey. The aptly named Goldmember has an affinity for all things gold, and he is supposed to be the driving force behind the evil schemes, yet his character is completetly futile in terms of plot development and those who saw the film, know there isn't even any closure to this character. The question arises - Will there be another Austin Powers film? If it is as recycled as this film was, many will take a pass at it. Some may be asking by this point, why so harsh? It is very simple. Avid fans who have come to know and love the immortal Austin Powers character know the man behind the character; Mike Myers, is a very talented and creative man. Insiders have always claimed many of the intuitive ideas were spawned from Myers and his thorough involvement within the script contributed to the success of the two films. Alas, this cannot be said for the third As aforementioned, from the musical introductory sequence, a morbid feeling came rushing over me as if to say, 'have they already used up all their ideas?'. Yes they have. Director Jay Roach (Meet the Parents, Austin Powers) returns to helm the third installment in what proves to be a disappointing foray into comedy. Roach tries his best at simply running the camera as many of the skits seem to be strictly improvised grounded in about a couple of sentences of script. The key word is skit. This film lacks cohesiveness due to a complete omission of plot. The film mentions something about kidnapping Austin Powers' father (Sir Micheal Caine) and having Goldmember destroy the world. The gags have all been done before and this time, the audience is laughing at recycled elements from the first two films thrown into a pot. This film is like a best of gag reel and amalgamates all the best elements of the first two films and brings them together. It is simply a running skit of gags that in terms of story, do not contribute to one another. Remember the shadow scene from the second film, it is here. Remember the rivalry between Dr. Evil and his son Scott, it is here too. Remember the sequence where they get around saying a graphic word by alluding to it by spotting things in the sky (a la 'Hot Dog' skit in the second film), it is here also.Spunk and creativity are lacking as the film takes on an uncomfortable tone of dismal classiness. The first two were funny, raunchy and wholesome films. This film will guarantee you many laughs, but when the film is over, one will be asking themselves what they were laughing about. It is that exact mindlessness that works against the film. So many times there were scenes that did not elicit laughs from the audience, yet they were still included in the final cut. A lot of little 'bits' in the film did not work, it seemed like a bad high school variety show at some points, but they were still in the film. It is inexplicable when there are uncomfortable pauses within in a comedy, something is incorrect. Adding to the demise of the film is Beyonce Knowles. A singer who makes her acting debut as Foxxy Cleopatra. A Hybrid of Shaft and Jackie Brown all rolled into one. Her character is endlessly annoying and is simply present to prompt awareness about Austin's biracial preferences. In any event, the film will elicit many laughs merely due to the immaturity of the jokes and the recycled cliches brought together. Will it leave the viewer with a dire need to watch it again as in the first two films, sadly no. This time, Austin is not shagadelic.Giancarlo's Rating: **</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

Remember the sequence where they get around saying a graphic word by alluding to it by spotting things in the sky (a la 'Hot Dog' skit in the second film), it is here also.Spunk and creativity are lacking as the film takes on an uncomfortable tone of dismal classiness. The first two were funny, raunchy and wholesome films. This film will guarantee you many laughs, but when the film is over, one will be asking themselves what they were laughing about. It is that exact mindlessness that works against the film. So many times there were scenes that did not elicit laughs from the audience, yet they were still included in the final cut. A lot of little 'bits' in the film did not work, it seemed like a bad high school variety show at some points, but they were still in the film. It is inexplicable when there are uncomfortable pauses within in a comedy, something is incorrect. Adding to the demise of the film is Beyonce Knowles. A singer who makes her acting debut as Foxxy Cleopatra. A Hybrid of Shaft and Jackie Brown all rolled into one. Her character is endlessly annoying and is simply present to prompt awareness about Austin's biracial preferences. In any event, the film will elicit many laughs merely due to the immaturity of the jokes and the recycled cliches brought together. Will it leave the viewer with a dire need to watch it again as in the first two films, sadly no. This time, Austin is not shagadelic.Giancarlo's Rating: **</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-24</date>
		<username>Erik</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>So much pop, it will make your teeth rot.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was terrible. It was a constant reminder that Hollywood needs some original ideas.Austin Powers: Oldmember, err I mean Goldmember, is another chapter in the life of Austin Powers. (Don't worry, there are no spoilers that will jeopardize the movie).Austin has to hunt down some old gezzer named Goldmember, how original. Dr. Evil and Goldmember are partners because they want to rule the world, blah blah blah, you get the idea. This movie had so many pop stars I wanted to kill myself; with talent less silicone infested people like Britney Spears, to the dysfunctional, brainless, prince of stuttering Ozzy Osbourne, this movie was crawling with celebrities that shouldn't even be in the film. I never did understand why all these celebes were in the movie, was Mike Myers trying to take a page from Moby? or just to say, "Look, these are my friends."I'm not going to lie, I was so tired of seeing commercial after commercial of Austin Powers, but when I seen the movie, it wasn't all that's cracked up to be, and now I am REALLY tired of seeing these obsolete commercials of Austin Powers. Well, on a more softer side to Austin Powers, Myers tried to make Austin out to be the victim when his father was never there for him; aahhh, my black heart bleeds for him; the chemistry between Austin and his father does not click with me, it was so dry of a good relationship.Saying Mike Myers is a comic genius is like saying Fred Durst or Kid Rock are brilliant lyricists, it's just not true. Austin Powers wasn't funny, the acting was terrible, and the characters had the worst dialogue in the world. Also, what is with the dancing? Come on, this movie was WORSE than Crossroads, and THAT should tell you something.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-24</date>
		<username>Elissa</username>
		<score>0.9</score>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-24</date>
		<username>paul_supercala</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Exactly what you'd expect, but worth it if you've enjoyed the other ones.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>One of the things about sequels that make people lose interest is the redundancy in material. It's one thing to base your movie on an idea and bring it in a new direction, it's another to rehash and barely expand on what you have. So many good films have lost their luster simply by trying to cash in on the original's good name. Even this summer we have seen "Men In Black II", "Stuart Little 2", and even "Halloween 8" degrade the spirit of the original. The new Austin Powers movie is guilty of all of the above, but by far the least of the offenders. It offers not much unexpected after the first five minutes, but still lies in the "guilty pleasure" realm that many critics prefer not to go into.So is the new Austin Powers worth going to see? Yes, if you're a big fan of the series. It offers plenty of laughs and succeeds in keeping its particular audiences' attention. Although considered "mindless" by some, there's actually quite a lot of thought put into it. Almost every scene is at least fairly funny and there's enough going on to keep even the most ADD glued to the screen.While there's no sort of award for comic performance in film, you've got to hand it to Mike Myers for providing pop culture with some of the most memorable comedic characters in quite some time. As one of the few post-SNL crew that make movies that matter (at least financially), Myers has brought us Austin, Fat Bastard, Dr. Evil, and now Goldmember. While the latter is probably the least likeable of all of his creations, it's still quite something to see someone handle four very different main roles by himself and do it well.Returning director Jay Roach knows not to fix what's not broken and keeps things rolling along with all of the usual stuff you'd suspect along with the aforementioned dazzling celebrity-ridden first five minutes. Michael York, Seth Green, Mindy Sterling, and Verne Troyer also all return to their now famous roles and are joined by the worthy Beyonce Knowles and Michael Caine. If it seems all too familiar, it's because it is supposed to be.This one is worth going to check out if you enjoyed the other ones. You'll get what you expect and if that's what you're looking for then Mike Myers and Co. did a good job. It wasn't made for critics, so it's up to you to decide if this is something you want to see.</fullReview>
	</review>

This is so far off the scale, I would only call it a complete waste of film. True humor can be great, This is Awful. What happened to Hollywood?A film lover</fullReview>

		<username>janyeap</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Yeah, baby, yeah... they are potty!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you're looking forward to a bucket of hip-hop, pop-culture gags, quirky movie spoofs, and character punches, this movie won't be a disappointment. It has a choc-a-block of colorful characters, zapping at the charm of the classic musical shows (hey, never thought that I'd ever imagine 'Singing In The Rain' could be funny!), and providing mickey-punches on the '70s Blaxploitation films such as 'Goldfinger', but not without splatters of nudges on the '70s fads and characteristics to create the ever-so-familiar synergetic groovy Austin Powers appeal, so loved by the fans. It also makes a crack at the '70s disco wave.This flick offers no apologies for daring the viewers to slight at any human peculiarities and imperfections, as seen in the eyes of the beholder. Even diction and accents are never left out for laughter. Needless to say, the Mike Myers' villains continue to belong to a breed of very flamboyantly insane creatures. Yeah, baby, yeah, many of the actors of the last two films are back playing their respective roles in this campy flick - Verne Troyer (Mini Me,) Seth Green (Scott Evil,) Robert Wagner (Number Two) and Mindy Sterling (Frau Farbissina) and Michael York (Basil Exposition). Even Mr. Bigglesworth, the cat, has not failed to make his appearance! Yep, they are all back on screen with their unforgettable silly mannerisms.Can't say this movie lacks foul vibes and crude toilet innuendos. Hey, it's Special Agent Shagalicious, teaming up with his old flame, and doing his Shagadelic! In a funky sense, this movie embraces the freedom to be crazy and stupid, silly, idiotic and weirdly and wildly evil! It blasts the screen with amusingly blatant and sassy acts and dialogue. The acts of the characters appear more as being psychotic, celebratory and mischievously wacky than disgustingly crude. It's these acts and mannerisms that make the characters bizarre, weird and totally infectious. All are varied in their attitudes, putting the viewers through a non-stop ride of hilarities. Yep, this film is filled with adolescent potty humor. And yet, the film does not fail in referencing the characters' fears and hopes, their wishes and struggles, their ideals and goals.Interesting cameos - Tom Cruise, Gwyneth Paltrow, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito, Quincy Jones and Britney Spears - they definitely prove their point that they too can whip up some solid amusement, especially when they take the viewers by surprise. And fans of the Mike Myers' AP character are definitely in for a cool treat when they get flipped in to the teenage years of the heroic spy. Oh don't forget to lookout for the youthful Dr. Evil and his No. 2 too. And Michael Caine is great as Nigel Powers, offering loads of signals that he's a ladies man, yet retaining an air of mystery about his character. Beyoncé Knowles carries off her Foxxy Cleopata role beautifully. She's the best Foxxy I've seen. Overall, the cast is wonderfully entertaining. And there are some unusually catchy phrases. Oh, I do love the father-son ferociously wicked lingo!I should think this flick would do very well at the box-office!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-07-23</date>
		<username>droopymcc</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Don't expect it to collect many converts to the series.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The highly anticipated Austin Powers in Goldmember looked very funny in its trailers.; new characters, new era, plus returning favourites from previous instalments in the series. And while it is pretty funny, it just doesn't stand up to the first two.If you don't know Mike Myers's Austin character, then you've been living under a rock under an even larger rock. He plays a time-travelling, swingin', shaggin' British secret service agent, always trying to foil his arch nemesis, Dr. Evil (also Myers). The second movie, Austin Power: The Spy who Shagged Me brought new characters, like Fat Bastard (Myers again) and Mini-Me (Troyer) into the fold, recycling the best jokes from the first, while adding a new kick in the pants. Somehow, it still managed to be clever and, more importantly, extremely funny.Now comes Austin Powers in Goldmember and what can I say? They try doing to same thing again but this time, it's irrelevant. There are references to the first 2 movies, and we find out more about Dr. Evil parents, but we've seen the gags before in this very series. Heck, they even make jokes about re-doing the same material. And when the best laughs come from surprise cameos (and there are lots of them), that's not a good sign. Nevertheless, the movie does become pretty damn funny, once they have to establish a "plot" (something about Dr. Evil flooding the world). It really picks up once Dr. Evil and Mini-Me are in prison, singing "It's a Hard-Knock Life". Before that though, the movie is pretty lame. After that point we get to the funny stuff. 20 year old movie newcomer (and Destiny's Child's singer) Beyoncé Knowles provides the eye candy as Foxxy Cleopatra, a sassy, 70s Blaxploitation spoof, who somehow hooks up with Austin to fight evil. Michael Caine is just great as Austin's spy dad and Myers adds a 4th character under his belt, playing the title character of Goldmember, a dude from Holland with junk of gold.You may think, "Wow! This sounds great." And it does, but when you actually see, it, you're wondering why you're not laughing as hard as you should. The first movie was fresh and new. It was a small movie that didn't make much money in the theatres, earning a loyal video following. It was a clever, fish-out-of-water movie, sometimes poignant and most importantly, fall-down funny. The second, despite its rehashed jokes, somehow was funnier than the first, except without the newness of the original. But fans were so starved for new Austin material, they goggled it up. The third now comes and we realize that the freshness is gone. It's not new anymore. Sure, the gags are there, but the soul isn't. While not up to the standards of the first two in the series, Goldmember is still pretty funny, and is worth seeing if you're a fan. Just don't expect it to collect many converts to the series.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Walter (wfraga)</username>

		<shortDescription>Will be enjoyed by Austin fans, but it's the weakest of the three films.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Don't worry this review does not contain any spoilers! I got a chance to see a special screening which was presented by the Just for laughs festival in Montréal. The best parts were with old characters from the two first films. Unfortunately, the new ones (Nigel Powers, Foxxy Cleopatra, Goldmember) were not as memorable and brought nothing new to the film. The movie had it's funny moments, but they were far apart or repetitive from the two first films. The part that I enjoyed the less is when we learn something about Austin and Dr. Evil. IMO that that was completely unnecessary and just didn't work. I also was hoping to see some more jokes with Austin in the whole disco scene of the 70's. But that was not to be. Even the rivalry between Scott and mini-me could have been better and longer. As for the story, it seemed unfocussed, with to many ideas, probably from the fact that they were too many characters. One could almost say that they could have made two movies with all of these ideas. Overall it's clear that it's the weakest of the three films. Still, for those who likes the two first movies, you will probably still enjoy this ones (just as I did). For the others don't bother watching this one! I certainly hope that they don't make an Austin Powers 4. Because in the end of this film, they kind of show you where they would go with it, and it doesn't look like a good place.</fullReview>

		<username>sirdiddimus</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Goldmember = Not So Good</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>All of the early reviews I read for GOLDMEMBER were positive, so I was psyched about going to a special WNFZ radio station sponsored sneak preview of the latest installment of AUSTIN POWERS. Then I saw it. *sigh* It was really, really not as good as THE SPY WHO SHAGGED ME. Okay, granted, there were about six (maybe seven) really good laughs. They were just few and far between.I know it seems rather shallow to base an opinion of a movie on how many times you laugh, but with the AUSTIN POWERS franchise, you have to. Besides, IT'S A COMEDY! Think of THE SPY WHO SHAGGED ME. You didn't watch it for the incredible plot development. (And if you did, I'm really, really sorry.) You saw it to laugh. And I did. I laughed so hard my sides hurt when I left.But this time around, we've seen all of these jokes before. The musical numbers. The "That looks like a giant--[penis reference]." They're just kind of hackneyed. I wanted something new. The second AUSTIN POWERS had more laughs because it took the humor in different (although more disgusting) directions. It's like Mike Myers just took his last script, changed some wording, and threw it into the Hollywood movie-making machine.I will give the movie this: the opener is great. The cameos are hysterical. Then you get in to the rest of the movie, and it's like The M &amp; M Show (Mike Myers--get it?). Also, it's sloppy. And that's where the laughs fall flat. They're not even trying anymore. It feels like Mike Myers is too aware of his ability to create humor. He mugs at the camera as if to say, "It doesn't matter what I do--you WILL laugh." Well, I defy you, Mike Myers!!! I just can't laugh in the presence of comic arrogance. Unless it's my own.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Goldmember is the third installment of the James Bond parody series with Mike Myers as the befuddled spy. This time, Dr. Evil intends to use a laser beam to melt the polar ice caps and flood the world. Meanwhile, Powers is being knighted, and about to hook up with twins, Fook Mi and Fook Yu, when he hears of his father's kidnapping by Goldmember; a variation of Goldfinger. He and Foxxy team up to find his dad. They encounter a new villain, a sumo wrestler named Fat Bastard; played by Myers in a fat suit. We also are introduced to Austin's father, Nigel, and Dr. Evil's son, Scott. Mini-Me, the midget from the first two films is also back. Myers is very funny and adding Beyonce and Michael Caine to the absurdity, makes it worth the ride.</fullReview>

		<date>2009-01-29</date>
		<username>michael_the_nermal</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>Thankfully the End of Austin Powers</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Just as one would expect, the "Austin Powers" movies got lamer with each showing. The first was alright: it wasn't the best comedy in the world, but at least Dr. Evil was amusing to listen to. The second catapulted Mini-Me into the pop culture landscape for a time, but was a passable effort with not much that was funny. The last "Austin Powers" movie (so far) is the worst. Mike Myers really strains himself to make the characters work, with little success. The jokes and writing were dreadfully uninspired and lacking in any form of wit (except for the final scene with the fat guy; I won't ruin it, and that's why I awarded an extra star to "Goldmember."). Very boring. Michael Caine doesn't really do much as Austin's father; not an interesting character in the least. Austin is boring, and Dr. Evil and Mini-Me doing hip-hop in prison looks so trite and unoriginal that I wonder why people who write these movies make oodles of cash. The character of Goldmember sucked. His accent and quips were the stupidest things I've ever heard. You can probably create better comedy in your sleep, and it would be better than the character Myers has created.This movie also has the most blatant product placement I've ever seen. It's already bad enough that there are TV commercials for cars and chewing gum before the previews; why do we need advertising IN the movies. Yeah, the movie makers stand to make a fortune, but it really shows how utterly crass movies have become.Steven Spielburg, Gwenyth Paltrow, John Travolta and Britney Spears make cameos, showing how in love with itself and out-of-touch with reality Hollywood is. Let's hope that this film is the last we'll see of Austin Powers for some time.</fullReview>

Also, Austin has a new girl and Beyonce is the weakest of the Austin girls by far. 		<shortDescription>Star cameos and outrageous toilet humor, some of which is very funny...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Third Austin Powers spy-spoof is nearly a winner for Mike Myers, playing the would-be suave International Man of Mystery once again pitted against Dr. Evil, who has hatched a plot to flood the world. Evil is now in cahoots with Goldmember, a power-mad genius from 1975 who sports a golden phallus. Surprise star-cameos and lots of funny raunch, yet the film still can't top the naughty-but-innocent initial entry in this series, which looks positively sedated next to this installment and the misguided second, "The Spy Who Shagged Me". Still, "Goldmember" has imaginative set-pieces, great music and some completely inane but delightfully executed laughs. Pop-star Beyoncé Knowles is a natural on-screen playing Powers' sidekick Foxxy Cleopatra, but Michael Caine (as Austin's father) never gets a great scene. **1/2 from ****</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2006-04-02</date>
		<username>Bill Slocum (bill.slocum@gmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Mojo Meltdown</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Mike Myers suffers from an unsteadying case of star bloat in this third installment of his Austin Powers spy-spoof series, banking on the fact that his fans will want to see even more of him than they have in the prior films. They did, judging from the box office "Goldmember" got, but in retrospect this seems more a coyote-woman comedy, something you chuckle at in the theater but leaves you feeling ill and ashamed the next morning.Austin Powers (Myers) is hot on the trail of a new bad guy named Goldmember (Myers again), who has kidnapped Austin's father Nigel (Michael Caine) as part of a vague scheme for flooding the world hatched by that dastardly supervillian Dr. Evil (more Myers) and assisted by Fat Bastard (still more Myers).Any film that features four times as much Mike Myers as Mike Caine is leaking bad mojo. "Goldmember" certainly lacks balance. From the lame cameos by Britney Spears and the Osbournes that speak to how old this Austin installment quickly got, to the goofy close-ups of Myers dragging out punchlines in one of his many roles, "Goldmember" is less a comedy and more a celebration of how big a star Myers has gotten to be, an impression deepened by a DVD commentary track with Myers and director Jay Roach.Roach gushes over Myers' on-screen performance and laughs at his lame jokes like a spineless courtier. Was this what happened on-set?"Oh, Jay, I'm going to do this thing with Goldmember where I eat my own skin and quote song titles from the '70s, after which I say the name of the artist who performed the song in a lower voice, because the only thing funnier than saying "That's the way, uh-huh, I like it" is saying "KC &amp; The Sunshine Band" right after.""Brilliant, Mike, um, Mr. Myers. If Peter Sellers was still alive, he'd die of jealousy. You're like Chaplin, only more poignant and athletically gifted. Um, you haven't left me off the points on DVD sales, have you?"Goldmember is Myers' first weak character in the Austin Powers series, a chance for Myers to don another disguise, busk his way through another accent, and make another play for Sellers' comedy crown. Yet the most he can manage is roller-dancing in wooden clogs and saying lines like "I'm Dutch. Isn't that weird?" He sucks up a lot of the script, and most of what's left goes to Myers' other characters, none of whom are developed much further. Austin has Daddy issues while Dr. Evil performs a rap number with his clone Mini-Me that seems to belong on the MTV Music Awards, not here.Caine seems wasted telling Viagra jokes as an unreconstructed version of Austin and revealing his hatred for two things, "all people who are intolerant of other cultures, and the bloody Dutch." He's AWOL for most of the movie, and when he reappears at the end, it's for such a lame scene you wish he had stayed gone.Verne Troyer is great as Mini-Me, though, the one character Myers seems to respect as much as his own, and Troyer delivers with broad and witty pantomimes. Beyonce Knowles is the best newcomer as blaxplotation queen Foxxy Cleopatra. Though she's horribly underwritten as the film raises the idea of spoofing the 1970s before dropping it, Knowles shows off some nice comedy chops along with a drop-dead cinched waistline.Myers, on the other hand, seems to be getting fatter, especially around the head. Perhaps Roach needs to stage an intervention. If he can direct Barbra Streisand, maybe he can pull Myers back to create another Powers film as funny and charming as the first two.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Like tired, baby</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Myers goes to the well one more time in the third and one supposes (hopes?) final entry in the Austin Powers saga. The first two were some of the funniest film-making of the last 20 years, the second getting fantastic mileage out of reconditioning much of the schtick from the first. The mojo is pretty much gone by #3, which even the presence of Caine (in the conceptually-inspired role of neglectful dad) can't save. Lack of chemistry between the leads, not enough creative effort, concept worn thin? You got me. Any time one of the primary running jokes centers on a character's large facial mole you know the cupboard has run bare. If there's a fourth movie Myers will play all the roles and the credits will be real short. 6/10 for the (much fewer) gags that work.</fullReview>

		<date>2005-02-13</date>
		<username>Ryan</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Austin Should Have Stopped At One</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I really enjoyed the first Austin Powers (Mike Myers) movie, Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery. It was fresh, even though it was a retread of the James Bond movies, but more importantly it was funny. It was funny because a 60s swinger was in the politically correct 90s and have a very hard time fitting in. The second movie, Spy Who Shagged Me, was not as good as the first, mainly because it takes Powers back to the 60s, losing it's primary source of humor. Now, we have this train wreck of a movie, Austin Powers in Goldmember, a movie that looks like a boat who has lost it's rudder. The only interesting character in the movie is Austin Powers' father, played by Michael Caine, but is sorely underused. The Powers' babe of this movie is Beyonce, playing Foxxy Cleopatra in a Pam Grier-esquire homage to the blaxploitation movies of the 70s, though I do not remember a skin-eating Dutch man running Studio 54 in New York, or what ever the movie was parodying in that scene. The movie almost looks like there are too many ideas crammed into the 94 minutes of running time. The highlight of the movie is the first 5 minutes, when there are surprise cameos playing familiar characters, but the joy and surprise is done early, and the movie goes downhill from there. I do not know why Myers thinks it's cute to have Dr. Evil do silly musical numbers, or why mole jokes are funny. So much is wasted by the last two Austin Powers movies that it's really a shame. Sure there are funny moments. My favorite was when Godzilla is crashing through Tokyo (don't ask, it's not that important), but the laughs are few and far between. If there is a forth Austin Powers movie, let's hope that they get back to the basics, Austin Powers trying to figure out where he is in life when living in the 1990s or early 2000s, still trying to figure out how Liberracce became gay.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>MF210</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Sometimes the comedy is inventive and sometimes its derivative</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My Rating: **1/2 out of ****.The third film in a movie trilogy is most of the time the worst. Austin Powers in Goldmember definitely proves that point. This is not a bad movie but it clearly shows in areas that Mike Myers was running out of ideas.The first two Austin Powers were enjoyable and fresh. Mike Myers clearly showed that he was talented. Goldmember is watchable but not always fresh. The viewer will clearly see that some jokes from the second film are reused here and they are not funny this time around. The behind the tent joke is there (when it looks like Austin is doing something nasty but really is not) and a boob satellite joke (Replacing the penis rocket from the second one) are not really funny here.Then again there is somethings inventive here. There is a clever bit when Austin is talking to the head of a Japanese corporation and the subtitles are cut off by an object to make it look like something dirty is being said. That was particularly funny. The beginning is certainly inventive and very cool and funny.Mike Myers gave 2 performances in the first Austin Powers(Austin and Dr. Evil) and 3 performances in the second (Austin, Dr. Evil, and Fat Bastard). Myers is trying to outdo himself here by giving 4 performances by adding a new character called Goldmember. Alot of people said he was really pushing it when he added Fat Bastard in the second film but I thought Fat Bastard offered his share of laughs. However, Goldmember is a mockery of Dutch people that seems more offensive and irritating than funny. Besides Goldmember, I mostly enjoyed watching Myers.Beyonce Knowles is the new girl alongside Austin. Knowles is not bad but she is not as good as Hurley and Graham were. Michael Caine is fine as Austins Dad but the surprise ending when he reveals a "shocker" is lame.Despite some derivative comedy and a lame ending, Goldmember is worth watching. I dont know about an Austin 4 though. This series seems to be running out of ideas.</fullReview>

		<username>Ecto-Jedi</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>The only "Austin Powers" movie that had me cringing...And that's not a good thing!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Austin Powers: Goldmember" tries to cap the successes of its predecessors by bringing back some now-classic characters and recycling old formulas --- but it doesn't quite work.SNL veteran Mike Myers returns as Austin Powers, the role that propelled him into the media's attention. However, "Goldmember" lacks the staying power of the first two films, and seems to be trying too hard to convince us that it's a funny movie. Given, the film did provide some laughs (especially from the portly Fat Bastard), but the funny moments are overshadowed by completely odd and embarassing moments that harass the experience. The dialogue this time around isn't as sharp as the previous installments, and the comedy is forced and unnatural at times --- plus, Michael Caine as Power's father is just about the worst casting call of the year..."Austin Powers: Goldmember" isn't a horrible flick, and, sure, it'll provide you with some laughs. Unfortunately, I didn't quite enjoy the experience. If Myers wants to stay on top of his game, he needs to ditch the old "Austin Powers" franchise and move on to new things.For a sequel to be good, it needs to bring us back all the great elements that were in the first films, but also bring something new and fresh into the mix that will make it a worthwile watch, and not just a re-hash of prior successes... By really not giving us anything new, "Austin Powers: Goldmember" fails to bring us anything worth watching. Skip this dull re-hash and stick to watching the previous installments.</fullReview>
