		<date>2002-09-22</date>
		<username>stamper</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Austin Powers reclaims his mojo</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Goldmember is really much better than the first Austin Powers sequel, entitled The Spy who shagged me. Although there are some similar jokes, this one gets off much better. It seems that there are some standard sort of jokes, sequences or quotes that have been used in previous Austin Powers movies and will be used again in upcoming Austin Powers movies. Things like 'the laugh' by Dr.Evil and his crew, the 'shush thing' between Dr.Evil and his son Scotty or Austin's rambling when he finds something so amusing he must tell three jokes about it. All of this is very much like the standard lines and or fragments there are in James Bond films. The typical: 'Bond, James Bond' or the exploding stuff in Q's lab or even the Miss Moneypenny dialogues. Nonetheless, this film is enjoyable and exciting, more then it's predecessor and even a bit more than the original. The cause for that, is that there are more jokes that will make you laugh like an idiot (because the joke is idiotic) and because the actors are much better than in The spy who shagged me. Contrary to that film and very much in line with International man of Mystery, the casting has chosen for quality actors and actresses. There is no young number two and no Felicity Shagwell, who were not good and pretty but shallow respectively. Rather we have Foxxy Cleopatra and Nigel Powers. Beyoncé Knowles from Destiny's Child (Foxxy) succeeds in being Foxxy and in portraying a good and likeable character, whereas Michael Caine (Nigel Powers) also succeeds in portraying a good daddy Powers. Verne Troyer (Mini-Me) is even better than he was in The spy who shagged me. He was good before, but he is just hilarious this time around. Mike Myers (Austin/Goldmember/Fat Bastard/Dr.Evil) is as good as ever. I mean he is just great, making silly faces and putting on foreign accents. In spite of the returning characters and the new ones, there are quite a few celebrity cameo's, none of which were annoying by the way. If that alone is not reason enough to watch this film, I don't know what is. If even Britney Spears, the queen of actresses (smirk), does not succeed in f..king up this film , nobody will!!! I mean she is not too bad on the eye, but acting is nothing for her. That girl (woman maybe) can't so much as sing a note properly (unlike miss Knowles), so how can one expect her to act even average. She cannot even perform average in her own profession (or is her profession not singing, but rather walking around with very few, tight clothes???). In addition to the very good acting (this is a spoof you know!), there is lots of variation, for there are moments of pity, moments of wonder, moments of stupidity and a many moments of laughter. I can't wait for the fourth in the series (I know there will be one), but what will it be called?7,5 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Awful!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When the original Austin Powers came out, I was pleasantly surprised. The movie was amusing, the parodies were well executed and the comedy was spontaneous. Most importantly, the movie had a sense of flow. Watching the second Austin Powers was more of a chore, with lots of uncomfortable lags and plenty of holes (Heather Graham was terrible in that movie).When the previews came out for the third installment, I was reluctant. After all, I had remembered how bad the second movie was, and the casting of Beyonce Knowles sent up all sorts of alarms off in my head. However, I was swayed by the positive reviews from the mainstream critics. I put aside my prejudice, paid my $7.00 and saw the movie. Boy, I wish I could have that $7.00 back.This movie was so slow and beyond unfunny, I was in a state of disbelief for about two hours after it ended. I couldn't believe that someone could allow such a rancid product to hit the movie theaters. People can defend this movie left and right, but the fact is, no one in the theater was laughing. I can't imagine anyone who isn't ridiculously biased could have possibly enjoyed this movie. I suppose it is all about money. I wonder how many critics the studio bought with all those product placements.My grade: 2/10</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-11</date>
		<username>mattymatt4ever</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Gets hilarious towards the end, but overdoses on the crude humor</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Now, I must admit the second "Austin Powers" movie did contain a hell of a lot of crude and sexual humor, but it often worked and produced hilarious results. In other words, it wasn't cheap and pathetic, like many of the gags in this film.The movie starts out with a bang, with many surprise celebrity cameos popping up. There are other cameos that pop up throughout the course of the film, and I felt they brightened up this otherwise mediocre comedy.Every other gag in "Goldmember" involves farting, crapping or genitalia. It's a miracle it earned a PG-13. Other than a hilarious rap duet of "Hard Knocks Life" between Dr. Evil and Mini-Me, in which they wear gold chains and party with half-naked women, the first half is pretty weak. Most of it is spent trying to tie up loose ends, giving us backstories of Austin and Dr. Evil, even going as far as showing them as roommates back in college. Some of the plot is just plain silly.Every time someone asks me about this movie, the same question comes up: "Can Beyonce act?" The answer is yes. She's a fine actress, and I wouldn't be surprised to see her in more and more movies. Beyonce's acting wasn't the problem; it was the writing. But to be on the bright side, the film strengthens towards the end with some hilarious bits, including one where Austin stands on Mini-Me's shoulders and they pretend to be one person. He gets summoned to deliver a urine sample. Funny. Then him and Mini-Me go behind a screen, and it appears in silhouette like Austin is masturbating. Very funny. And there's another recycled bit from the second movie, where everyone looks up a spaceship shaped like a pair of boobs.I liked the first "Austin Powers," I loved the second one, but damn it it's time to retire the franchise. The first movie set up the joke, the second one played along with it and now the joke is dead and Mike Myers is succumbing to a barrage of cheap toilet humor. The "Wayne's World" franchise never tired out, because there were only TWO movies.The character of Goldmember isn't that funny. His running gag is that he talks funny English (just not funny enough to make me laugh). He also collects his dead skin and licks it. Disgusting, definitely. Funny, far from it. And I really wish they could've cast someone other than Michael Caine to play Austin's father. Not that his performance is flawed; it's just I find it almost vomit-inducing to watch an incredible actor making bad penis jokes.Is there gonna be an "Austin Powers 4"? I hope not. There are some cases, like in "Lethal Weapon" series, in which a movie is strong enough to spawn a couple of good sequels. This is not one of those cases.My score: 6 (out of 10)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I think it's safe to say that if you liked "Austin Powers International Man of Mystery" and "Austin Powers The Spy Who Shagged Me" then you'll probably enjoy this film as well. I'd have to say that I liked this film just as much as the other two films.The story is pretty much what you'd expect, and pretty similar to the first two films, but that is to be expected. There is a lot of regurgitated comedy from the first two films, but at the same time there is a lot of original comedy that just had me busting up.The cast is fantastic, Mike Myers is a comedic genius!!! And Jay Roach is a superb director! There are some films that you just don't want another director to touch, and I think this is one of those films. Michael Caine, Seth Green, Beyonce Knowles, Robert Wagner and Verne Troyer are just great in this film! I think it's great that Michael Caine agreed to do this film, and quite appropriate in that Mike Myers parodies some of Michael Caine's past films. I definitely have respect for actors that do diverse roles. There are quite a few cameo appearances in this film, but I won't mention any of them as not to ruin the surprise for you (although, if you're reading the review on this site you probably already know about them).I thought "Austin Powers in Goldmember" was a great addition to the Austin Powers franchise. I'm not really sure how they would do a 4th installment, but you never know. I hope you enjoy the film as much as I do. Thanks for reading,-Chris</fullReview>

Myers is one of the most gifted comedians ever, you have to laugh at some stuff. Moreover, I thought his Goldmember character was funny and not used enough. But overall, this movie plays like a bad series of SNL skits. There is a part in the film were Ozzy (yet another worthless cameo) complains that this movie is just rehashed and reused jokes. The so-called "hilarious" cameos in the beginning are mildly amusing at best, and the concept was basically ripped off from a similar stunt in "Pee Wee's Big Adventure" done well over a decade ago.</fullReview>

		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>It's over, this series has hit bottom....hard</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just got back from seeing this one and I have to say this is the first movie this year to completely disappoint me. It's just completely lacking anything to keep you interested. Sure all the people are back and all the jokes are in there that you would expect but it's just not funny this time.Now I expected to see a lot of the same things that were in the first two movies in this series. The Dr. Evil vs Scott game where Scott tries to talk and Dr. Evil tries to make him shut up, The Fat Bastard fixation on bodily functions and excrement jokes, and even the now classic Dr. Evil contacting the "World Government" and asking for a ridiculous amount of money to ransom the world were all right where I expected them to be.I'm not annoyed that they repeated all of this and I don't think that's the reason it wasn't funny this time around. I just think that on every one of the running gags they blew it. None of the actors seemed to be trying very hard and in almost every case the timing was off badly.The story is like some sad rip-off of the second one with less thought put into making it. The opening credits are funnier than anything else in the picture which makes for a really long movie.The girl from Destineys Child might be a hell of a singer but she couldn't act her way out of a paper bag. Mike Meyers Austin character seems really forced and he doesn't look like he's having much fun doing it. His Fat Bastard character doesn't do anything amusing and is completely wasted. The lines he has are just gross without any comedy involved. It's almost like Meyers thought FB could just show up and we would laugh. The whole movie feels this way.Goldmember (the character) doesn't even have a previous funny appearance going for him. He's just gross without a point and if possible less funny than everyone else around him.The first one I didn't think much of when I first saw it but it got funnier with time and after running into it a couple of times I could appreciate it for what it was. Obviously Dr. Evil stole the movie. The second one was better because it focused a lot more on the Dr. Evil character and it seemed clear that Meyers had figured out what people enjoyed about the series. This one looks like it was made so a lot of people could collect checks.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Jumbled, cheap, exploitative, greedy trash</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Mike Myers is developing something of an Anti-Midas touch. Everything he touches, he cheapens. Jokes, plotlines, respectable actors credibility, everything. The seedy decline of the Austin Powers franchise slides to a disgusting new low in Myer's latest desperate cash in attempt in Austin Powers: Goldmember. I won't ruin it for you, but I feel I owe you the advice...DO NOT SEE THIS FILM. The horror begins with a cheap, insencire cameorgy with uncomfaratable, hurried performances from actors painfully doing Myers a BIG favour. After that...well...coherence kind of crumbles away and yields to a disturbing collage of nonsencial, recycled, disgusting and sometimes frankly rather disturbing idiocy. Dr. Evil isn't funny. Austin Powers has lost all of his appeal entirely. His character has been reduced to a ring announcer in a circus of forced humour. He gleefully displays products for dozens of franchises, awkwardly shouts about the famous actors that have shown up for cameos, and looks generally more like Mike Myers in odd clothing than a fictional character. There was something about the original character as compared to this new, pseudo-self obsessive Michael Myers that made the whole 60s british swinger character original and hilarious. Dr. Evil and Austin Powers were JUST as hilarious. Now we have seen a disgusting degeration of talent. I felt raped by this movie. I felt ripped off, and I think Michael Myers owes me $6. He didn't have the right to do this to me. I can't get back those two hours I spent in front of that product placement laden feces party. The new character, Goldmember, is disgusting, offensive and disturbing. It is Myers trying to force humour from a situation that does not warrant any. Enough said. This is a shudderingly awful travesty of a film, and should never have been made. Take me seriously, it's a waste of your time.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Worst Movie Ever</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The 3rd Austin Powers movie tragically fails to not only bring justice to the trilogy, but to the movie industry in general. While attempting to close plot holes and introduce new characters, the movie sells out with advertisements and B grade celebrity cameo's (such as Britney Spears, whose presence displays a mockery of the entertainment industry in general). The portrayal of Dr Evil also tragically does no justice to the original movie. Dr Evil was a recreation of a classic Bond villain, who was a calm and twisted genius. The funniest part of Dr Evil was that behind his maniacle smile, his plots fell apart. Adding the dancing, songs, and ability to get out of his chair (a joke from the first movie) took away from the originality that made him funny. Overall, his character is ridiculously over-the-top. Additionally, there aren't any new jokes behind the glitz or glamour. Instead, the movie tries to sell the audience on repeated gags and finished plot lines that ultimately make this movie a wasted ticket. Furthermore, it takes away from the innovative style Myers brought to the forefront when he introduced the Powers character. Overall, don't see this movie. Buy the first Austin Powers and forget that the rest of them exist.</fullReview>

		<username>alecsaved</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>How could this be?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Austin Powers II is one of the few movies that I went to see twice at the cinema during its run there. I bought the DVD as soon as it came out and have watched it many times since. I mention this because I had high expectations for AP III. I could spend a lot of time extolling the comedic virtues of AP II, and then simply tell you that AP III has none of them.There are many scenes and devices from AP II that are re-tried in AP III. None of them work. The reason they do not work, in my opinion, is because instead of infusing more originality they just infused more vulgarity. Now mind you, I think a fart joke is as funny as the next guy, or my 8 year old daughter. There is hardly anything witty or original (as I mentioned) about this movie, but instead is a layering of silly, over-the-top bodily function and sexual humor. The script is hardly engaging, and the plot is confusing and disjointed. And Beyonce, she's no Heather Graham in any way shape or form. The Goldmember character is weak, not entertaining to look at, and does not play a prominent role in the movie when compared to Dr. Evil. They could not even get past him. And the ending... it's as schmaltzy as, well, an estranged family reunion.If you have not seen this movie, I suggest only watching it if you can borrow it from a friend, have 2 hours to kill (I started cleaning out the junk drawer in front of the TV after 20 minutes) and be prepared for an endlessly rippling wave of mindless low-bro 'humor'. If that's your thing, no doubt it's your friend's thing too and you have likely already been talked into seeing it or even own it.No wonder you can get the deluxe collector's edition at Columbia House for $5.95; it's hardly worth more. I highly recommend Undercover Brother - original and FUNNY.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I haven't seen the other 2 films in the series, so maybe I'm missing something. The first 5 minutes are eye-popping just for the sheer number and quality of cameos. 		<date>2004-02-24</date>
		<username>Peter Hayes</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Lame recap of previous efforts with a bigger budget but ever cheaper gags.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Here we go again in a series that is not so much a spoof, as a spoof on a spoof. The original Austin Powers was more a spoof on In Like Flint (with James Coburn), Jason King and the other swinging sixties anything-goes James Bond rip-offs than the real 007 movies.The franchise isn't really a series of films as such, but a chance to showcase Mike Myers talents in a series of guises including, for the first time, a mad penis painting Dutchman - Goldmember - who strangely doesn't even know his own language from German!(Maybe that was a deliberate mistake - who knows and frankly who cares?!)A success has many fathers, but failure is an orphan. Good to see that now we are on a winner we have star day players onboard to remind us that they too wouldn't mind a hit franchise (or two) of their own.The greatest thing about the script is that the target audience hasn't seen the original thing and there are still loads of old Benny Hill sight gags to steal.(You've been caught baby, yeah....)Every time the writers (which includes Myers) goes back to the series they merely add to what they have created before without discarding much. Michael Caine is added as Power's (mostly absent) father and Beyonce plays a foxy blacksploitation sidekick (very well acted too - bang on the money!), but we have nothing really that new on the menu. The rule of thumb being that as the gags get cheaper the sets get more expensive.No film has to be anything but a time passer, but what is evident here is that when you take away any element of danger or intrigue you have nothing to cling on to, even silly comedy needs a forward plot device.All-in-all a product that is more interesting off-screen that it is on. A money making machine that doesn't want to stop because behind the face-pulling and the look-at-us-we-can laugh-at-ourselves we have a serious business. This won't be last of the series because we have money being made and while money is being made no Hollywood franchise will be dropped. The only alternative is that Myers gets tired of getting tens of millions for his so-so performances. Who knows - maybe he has hidden ethics? Let us hope so.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen. The film is often annoying, has very little in the way of truly funny jokes, and is unoriginal. Beyonce Knowles is unamusing as Cleopatra, and often just stands around watching while Mike Myers mugs. She is not as effective as Elizabeth Hurley or Heather Graham. The character of Goldmember is ill-conceived and less than amusing. As my father, who watched it with me, noted, "The character wasn't even one dimensional; he's half-dimensional." The only jokes associated with him either fail to bring even a chuckle, or grow old very quickly. Finally, the film is laden with annoying celebrity cameos that distract from the action. 		<fullReview>The first two Austin Powers movies were very good. So it wasn't difficult to be anxious about seeing Part III. Normally I don't go out to the movies in order to catch the `latest and greatest' features that are out, so I usually wait for them to become available for home viewing. My daughters saw this film on the wide screen and liked it. Compared to this one, the first two Austin Powers movies were exceptionally good and funny, especially The Spy Who Shagged Me. To put it mildly, I was extremely disappointed in this film. This one is a first class stinker. It has more than the usual 8th grade level `bathroom humor' that normally accompanies modern comedies of this nature (remember Wayne's World?). However, the writers make a desperate attempt to keep the plot afloat by overdoing it a bit. Nonetheless, their attempt to use it to for the benefit of the plot fails miserably. Speaking of plot, there really is none. The overemphasized humor involving genitals and "soft core" swear words is stupid and adds to the absurdness of this movie. Film features cameos of Brad Pitt, Danny DeVito, Britany Spears and John Travolta among others in another possible attempt to add substance to the plot. Not!!! This stinker is a total schlockfest. This is just another example of the junk that is available for sale, while some great classic films from the 40's and 50's go unnoticed by the powers-that-be. Even the great classic `The Final Countdown' (1980) starring Kirk Douglas isn't available for sale, but this claptrap is. Go figure.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-02-14</date>
		<username>Michael DeZubiria (wppispam2013@gmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>AAAAHHHH no frickin' way!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Just in case you missed it in the last movie, the Austin Powers series has completely fallen off a cliff. The third installment in the Austin Powers series accomplishes little more than proving that the first sequel was not the full depth to which the series planned on sinking. The second movie fed completely off of the success and original comedy of the first movie, recycling the same jokes and trying vainly to get people to laugh at the same things, with a few new tasteless and downright bad jokes thrown in between. MiniMe and Fat Bastard (who, combined, provided about 20 seconds of amusement in the first sequel) are both back here and neither provides anything new or even anything amusing.There are sporadic moments in the film that are funny (even two scenes that made me laugh out loud), but they are so hidden in a slog of garbage that they are not worth the rest of the movie, and they're both only briefly funny anyway. There is a scene where Dr. Evil gets hit in the groin by a swinging object and screams out what you can find in the summary line of this review and, even better, Austin has a touching and lengthy flashback remembering his flaky father and how he was never there for him to see his accomplishments, and when he comes out of the memory and we see his emotion-stricken face, Dr. Evil (locked up in a glass cage like Dr. Lecter) says, 'Oh, boo-frickety-hoo!'That's funny, isn't it? Well, I laughed at it. But then you have to deal with the rest of the movie. The old scene with Dr. Evil and his son Scott arguing at the table is brought back from the dead, this time so overdone and so tired that it literally dissolves to the point where Dr. Evil is simply grunting and groaning and making strange noises, which I assume are meant to be funny. They're not. If you haven't, in fact, gotten to the point where you're raising your eyebrows and looking around at the people next to you to see if they're as mystified as you are about how this has gotten so bad, you definitely will here.Beyoncé Knowles plays the part of Foxxy Cleopatra, coming off as one of the most nerve-gratingly aggravating characters ever to set foot in this doomed series, and vainly trying to fill the tiny shoes of Heather Graham from the first sequel, who provided probably the first thoroughly boring character in the Austin Powers movies. Her wooden acting and total incongruity to the character she was playing made me think that they would have simply taken out the heroine completely for any third movie that they might be greedy enough to make, but instead they throw in the exact same thing. Both are characters put into the movies for no other reason than to have a popular face playing a tasteless character in an Austin Powers film.I think that the trilogy is such a common occurrence in movies that it's safe to say that this will be the last installment made in the Austin Powers series, but I think it's also worth mentioning that this is the first time I have ever made a specific effort to hypothesize about whether or not they will ever bombard us with another crapfest from a series of movies that is so obviously dead and gone (and I'm still terrified that someone is going to come up with the fool idea that they should make a third Scary Movie - I could stand about 25 more Austin Powers' movies before another one of those). The second movie should never have been made in the first place, and the third one is more than overkill.And by the way, I saw this movie at Leicester Square in London when I was in England doing a study abroad program through the University of California, Davis, studying Shakespeare in the summer of 2002. PLEASE believe that you have not the slightest idea of what I missed out on when I went to see this movie.</fullReview>
	</review>

The cameos made in this movie from such stars as Tom Cruise, Danny DeVito, John Travolta, and The Osbournes are also very funny. I would have to say that this would be a good contender for best comedy along with "Airplane." I recommend this to anyone who wants to be in stitches in the first 5 minutes of a movie.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Impressive</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>No spoilers - nothing, not a word, except 'impressive'. Myers has transcended his own career. Making this movie was a lot of work, by a lot of people. Meticulous writing, filming, editing - and with comedy, timing is everything, and here it works, and to a degree that is surprising. Sequels aren't supposed to be good - at least not as good as the original movie. Here we have the third movie in the series taking the idea, and the talent of the people behind the movie, to a whole new level.It's fun to speculate about what the next few movies in this series will be called. If Goldmember, the third, corresponds to the third 007 movie Goldfinger, and if the fourth 007 movie was Thunderball, then a first guess on number four in the Austin Powers saga is rather straightforward, is it not? And will You Only Live Twice - with reference to Dr Evil and Mini-Me - become You Only Live Once And A Half?Go see it - no joke: It's one of the best movies of the year.</fullReview>

After a pretty darn entertaining opening sequence, things take a turn for the sour - the character Goldmember is remarkably unfunny - I don't think he gets a single laugh the entire film, the product placement and obvious "MTV video" moments from The Spy Who Shagged Me are back and even more prevelent than before.SPOILERS - some of the cameos were extraordinarily humorous, without naming names, but the Britney Spears appearance was cold, calculated, and incredibly unfunny (the audience didn't react at all). And I enjoyed Mini-me more in this one than in the last. And as I said before, there ARE some good laughs. 		<date>2011-02-07</date>
		<username>jc-osms</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>For members only</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The attempted jokes come thick and fast and thin in this third and to date last outing for Mike Myers' parody of swinging 60's spy-romps, but by now familiarity was starting to breed contempt and as is usual the third time around, some situations are just pushed too far, going well beyond, for me anyway, acceptable boundaries of taste. And yes, I am thinking of what I'll politely call the bodily functions jokes which are played out for too long, outstaying their welcome every time. Add to this the mile-high overblown prologue where big-name Hollywooders demean themselves in knowing cameos, a plot that just won't start and some obvious in it either for the money casting (the Robert Wagner and Michael Caine pension schemes) or for the exposure (Beyonce Knowles in a part completely unsuited to her) so that you're grateful when the odd genuinely amusing moment does come along. Me, although I saw the punchline coming minutes before it arrived, smiled most at the Styx-ian pun on Mr Roboto, although I doubt many others outside North America would get the gag and there were a few other funny lines scattered throughout, but the law of diminishing returns was well in evidence to the extent that I think we can all be glad that Powers didn't return in "Austin-pussy" or "Thunder-balls".</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2009-04-07</date>
		<username>Electrified_Voltage</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Not usually that funny, definitely the weakest of the three</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I remember the first time I saw this third installment in the Austin Powers franchise. It was New Year's Eve in 2002, and I was sixteen years old. Before then, I had only seen bits of the first two. (I never watch sequels to movies I haven't seen anymore, but sometimes did then.) My first viewing of "Austin Powers in Goldmember" was definitely a good one, so I watched the first two within the next few weeks after that, in reverse order. For a while, I was a big fan of the franchise, but watching the entire trilogy again in recent years, I have discovered that I now think the first one, "Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery", is the best, and the two sequels (1999's "Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me" and then this one), each brought the franchise down a step.As usual, Dr. Evil has another plan for world domination, but soon after he announces it to his colleagues, Austin Powers comes to arrest him! However, the British secret agent is soon informed that his father, Nigel, has been kidnapped, so he goes to talk to his foe in prison! He learns that a Dutch man from the 1970's known as "Goldmember" was involved in this abduction, so he travels back to 1975! At Goldmember's club, Powers meets Foxxy Cleopatra, an FBI agent working undercover. They witness Nigel Powers captured and taken through a time machine to 2002, so Austin then takes Foxxy back to 2002 with him. Dr. Evil and Mini-Me soon escape from their maximum security prison, and join Goldmember in a dastardly plot to cause a global flood! Obviously, it's up to Austin Powers and his new sidekick to try and stop them! Mike Myers played two roles in the first film (Austin Powers and Dr. Evil), and added a third alter ego (Fat B%$#&amp;*%) in the second, so it's no surprise that he plays a fourth one in this third installment, Goldmember. I no longer care much for Fat B%$#&amp;*%, which includes his appearance in this film, with scenes involving more toilet humour, and jokes about his sumo wrestling diaper, but Goldmember might be worse. I don't think I was ever a huge fan of his, but used to find him more acceptable. His exaggerated Dutch accent is supposed to be funny, but it's actually perhaps a little irritating. The film isn't completely straight-faced, it has its moments, such as Austin Powers unable to keep quiet about the mole on Number Three's face, and another crude shadow gag (like the one in "The Spy Who Shagged Me"). However, the laughs in this film are still smaller in number than they are in its two predecessors, and it may get even more juvenile here than before. In the role of Austin Powers' sidekick, Beyoncé Knowles puts on a better performance than Heather Graham did in the first sequel, but that doesn't make this film superior."Goldmember" is obviously partially a spoof of "Goldfinger", the 1964 adaptation of the James Bond novel of the same name. Unfortunately, this third Austin Powers installment is far inferior to that third James Bond flick from 38 years earlier. On the other hand, "Austin Powers in Goldmember" is definitely better than "Die Another Day", the Bond film which came out the same year. If you ask me, that film, the twentieth installment in the franchise, and Pierce Brosnan's last outing as Bond of four, is undoubtedly the worst Bond flick to date! Nonetheless, this second sequel to Mike Myers' James Bond spoof showed that the series may be wearing thin, and although it's been nearly seven years since it came into theatres, it looks like a fourth Austin Powers movie has been confirmed. I'm not going to ignore it when it comes out, but since each of the two sequels brought the franchise down a step, it wouldn't surprise me if Austin Powers 4 brings it down yet another step, then it would follow the pattern.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2008-09-17</date>
		<username>Robert F. Dale</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>An average comedy.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I love the Austin Powers series, but I feel like this effort was my least favorite of the three thus far. If you were to watch the first movie, then the second, and then finally "goldmember," you will undoubtedly see how the characters become so overblown by the third film, drastically different then how they were in the first film. Take for instance Dr. Evil, who in the first movie was almost serious, and anything comedic was often very subtle, not trying for the laughs, but getting them in a unique fashion. In "goldmember," however, evil is completely out of character and it gets almost ridiculous at times. Although these characters are all funny, they've all gone through their own "personal evolution." "goldmember" is filled with many memorable moments which is why I still have respect for the series. The opening of the movie is probably one of the greatest openings for a comedy I have ever seen. I'm sure many can agree to that. The whole part with Mr. Roboto is witty and smart, poking fun at our use of subtitles. The movie also has another great scene behind a curtain, which mirrors another scene in the second movie, where it looks like heather graham is pulling grenades, rats, umbrellas, and other objects out from Austin's behind. However, the scene in "goldmember" involves Austin and Mini Me in a hospital room during a rountine physical. I also have respect for Mike Myers himself, who plays the parts of 4 characters in Austin, Dr. evil, fat bastard, and goldmember. So all in all, an alright comedy. It has its moments, but it also has those moments that just go too far and are completely off base with what the first movie in the series was trying to illustrate. I've heard that a fourth picture is most likely in the works, which I hope they can turn around the series with a final movie that Austin Powers fans truly deserve.</fullReview>
	</review>

A new addition to Myers's cast of characters - the absurdly unfunny title character Goldmember - adds little to proceedings. 		<date>2008-01-13</date>
		<username>ntvnyr30</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Embarrassingly Unfunny</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film ranks up there (or is it down there) with some of the worst films I have ever seen. This undistinguished list includes this film, "Black Sheep", "Superman III", "Q &amp; A", and on and on...Unlike the previous two AP films, I did not laugh out loud once. I loved the Jerry Springer bit in the 2nd film, as well as the "Alan Parsons Project" as well as the interplay between Dr. Evil and Scott and other bits too.This one was completely awful. I sat there wanting and expecting to laugh and it never came. I wouldn't doubt if another film was released only not to have this piece of rubbish as the epitaph.But the best observation I can make is that there is no direct relation to how much money a film makes (or for TV shows, how high the ratings)and the quality of the film. Case in point: this film made much more than the first two, and yet it blew. Also, consider the fact that the best Star Wars film (which almost no one contests) was "The Empire Strikes Back". This film made the least money of all the Star Wars films. A TV example is "The Simpsons". The show is almost unwatchable now---just a collection of gags and every one of the family acts like an idiot. Contrast this to the first few seasons, where Marge and Lisa were the sane ones in the family, and the shows actually had a believable underlying plot. Now it's total chaos on the show, and yet it still gets ratings. I think that the general public is behind the power curve, because I'm not certain what they're laughing at--maybe the history of the show. I think it's the same with David Letterman--he used to be much, much funnier when he was on NBC. He was irreverent, and now he's a left-wing Ed Sullivan. The audience laughs at jokes that are just not funny. Again, it's the expectation and the fact that people are behind the power curve. And it's no different with this film.</fullReview>
	</review>

Definitely the first Austin movie was nice, although just a joke after another but they were good jokes and yes so separated but so is every single sequence of a Bond movie except we're talking here comedy not action ! The sequel (Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me) did nothing but repeating the first with much of absolute dirty jokes and heavy human excrement humor. I didn't like it but it did very very well at the box office though. HERE, at the third one, you won't find any respectable comedy at all (even by the Powers/Myers's measurements !!). Save just the intro, it's a flood of pure filthy verbal or visible jokes, and very unfunny ones by the way ! It's disappointing because Myers got no new thing to present, and because THAT KIND OF JOKES is pretty easy &amp; truly nauseating. I was sad to see (Michael Caine) doing nothing but commenting about Mini-me's penis, Mini-me showing his naked butt to the people, one character eating his skin, or Myers's endless dry jokes about moles. It's bad tasting at its top and its failure too. So how about being the totally unfunny installment of what used to be nice parody!Now what you'll say if you knew that there is more than 60 minutes of deleted scenes as well ?? Of course the question will be : is it the REAL good thing which we've never seen of Goldmember ?, or it is more and more of the gross comedy which we get it from any dirty-minded young man with too much of empty time!!?Once I heard that the talent of comedy is a proof of being intelligent. Myers confirms here that he's turning into idiot! It's clear that in his third movie as Austin he ran out of good ideas so he easily chose to take the staircase of dirty jokes, but in this very case he got the way down! One last thing : I'm totally crazy about Beyoncé Knowles (Foxy Cleopatra indeed !) her voluptuous body, her good singing and dancing (or her dancing booty in specific.. Ahh!). But here she is doing the big nothing ! Just beautiful eyes, a nice smile, and not even much of a role (like the one Elizabeth Hurley had at the first movie !!), or a good sexy shots (like what Heather Graham got and delivered in the second one !!). I hoped for some sweet dancing or some of her famous booty SHAKING which is great (the booty and the SHAKING !) but there is nothing at all!Finally, I'm sad to say that I didn't enjoy it AND I'm trying to forget it too !</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Not a bad movie at all. He isn't particularly interesting. He's not as evil as Dr. Evil, and not as disgusting as Fat Bastard, and comes off as a washed out amalgam of the two.Fred Savage, from TV's "The Wonder Years," is good in his two scenes as "the Mole." It's Dr. Evil, as usual, who steals the show, however. And it's a pretty good show.Rating: BF.Y.I.: While in the movie we hear ELO's "Evil Woman," King Floyd's funk classic "Groove Me," and Bobby Darin's "Beyond the Sea," Darin's song is not on the soundtrack, and absolutely awful cover versions of the first two make the album. Avoid this soundtrack at all costs!</fullReview>

The other addition is Austin's father Nigel (Michael Caine).Anyway, "Austin Powers in Goldmember" is raucous fun from beginning to end. You just have to remember not to take anything seriously - and believe me, you can't. Reprising their roles from the earlier movies are Seth Green, Michael York, Robert Wagner, Mindy Sterling and Verne Troyer, while the guest appearances this time are Fred Savage, Steven Spielberg, Tom Cruise, Gwyneth Paltrow, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito and Britney Spears.And that's life, baby!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Some funny bits, and mostly it delivers</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I thought that one of the cleverest ways to attack this movie is just what Mike Myers did. He made fun of the fact that he was re-using the same jokes over from the last two Austin films. As in the part where he very randomly starts in on Scott for no reason, and Scott's reaction is "Oh wait this is very familiar, let me do what I do". Brilliant. However there are parts in the movie where this concept doesn't carry as well as it does there. The Fat Bastard bits seemed forced, although the wire gag was funny. The shadow puppet bit that was done much better and funnier in the second movie. What saves this movie really from being a re-run is the conflict with Austin's father, and the new villain Goldmember. Michael Caine is excellent and refreshing as Austin's father, although it was almost a little too much drama than I wanted when i pay to see an Austin Powers movie. But Goldmember is spot on. He is hilarious, and the best part about him is he's original! Loved every scene he was in and thought that he was VASTLY underused for having the movie named after him. It was like here's DR. EVIL! 		<username>Devin (d_e_v_i_n-1)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>If he were any cooler, he'd still be frozen, baby!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>You're probably all familiar with Austin Powers and his travels. If not, think James Bond meets 60's porn star, with a little chest hair, rather large glasses and a great set of teeth thrown in for good measure. The previous two films saw Powers battle with world-domination freak Dr.Evil (played by Myers again), and in the third he is well and truly back again.After a brilliantly creative opening sequence featuring some of the best spoofs of recent times as well as a handful of star cameos, we learn that Dr.Evil is again making crazy attempts to conquer the world. Mini-me, his trusty sidekick is well and truly back, though he never reaches the same heights as the previous film. When Austin manages to foil Dr.Evil's plans early into proceedings you'd be forgiven for thinking the story is about to go absolutely nowhere. And in true Austin Powers style it doesn't, though there's still some semblance of a plot so that all those familiar situations from the last two films can be rehashed.The film isn't without it's flaws but you can never go past the fact that it's just plain fun. Most of the old jokes aren't nearly as funny the third time around and some of the new jokes fall flat but there's still some really funny stuff in there amongst it all. If only Myers hadn't taken tired gags from various other sources to pad things out a little then it would've been as original as his previous two Austin movies.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Star Power Worthy of Watching !!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Third in the Trilogy of Austin Powers films created by Mike Myers,"Goldmember" has Star Power and fine performances, but fails when it runs out of ideas . The opening sequence comes out swinging.It is one of the most creative and inventive uses of the medium. As a matter of fact the first half of the film is very good, unfortunately, it fails to maintain the same creative energy, when Myers goes back to using bodily fluid jokes ad infinitum.The character of "Goldmember"(Mike Myers),threatens the world with demolition, if his demands are not met.Austin Powers teams up with his father Niles Powers(Michael Caine)and Foxy Cleopatra(Beyonce' Knowles), Austin's current Love interest, to defeat Goldmember, Dr. Evil and the rest of the Clan.Their adventures take them thru time to the swinging 60's and back to the present, with a major twist in Dr. Evil's lair near the end !Michael Caine has great comic timing, when he has material to work with, he should have been given more. Beyonce' steals her scenes with terrific moves and talent that just radiates from the screen . Verne Troiyer is wonderful as the vertically challenged Mini-Me. Watch for the transformation of Seth Green into a Ron Howard lookalike.Unfortunately, with all of the Star Power, the script lags the talent, and you have too many people , standing around as filler. All in all, a fun time, if you can forgive the script and Myers for not providing more for the film !</fullReview>

		<username>Cephyran</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>funny but weaker...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Austin Powers is funny. Kind of silly funny, like almost every character associated with Mike Myers. and, as much as I enjoyed Goldmember, I felt is was likely the weakest of the trilogy. Myers returns as the swinging sixties sexy superspy, and this time he finds that Dr Evil and a villain named Goldmember are in cahoots to, once again, try and hold the world ransom, lest terrible things happen. Teamed up with Beyonce Knowles as the sexy agent Foxy Cleopatra and the cinema superstar Michael Caine as his father, Austin has to defeat Dr Evil and Goldmember. So, the humor came rolling a mile a minute. Problem is, some of the stuff is only funny the first time you see it, and then you have to wait a really long time to forget about it before watching it again. And that's partly the problem - a lot of Myer's humor is repetitive, and more often than not vulgar (although it's guaranteed to get laugh from the 13 year old boys demographic). And some of the characters were excessive to the already packed runtime. For example, Fat Bastard, the portly Scottish lackey, didn't even need to be in this movie - he didn't exactly contribute much to the plot. To a lesser extent, there was less focus on Dr Evil than on Goldmember - you'd expect this, because of the title, but it just seems to grind away at the movie. Overall, I have to say it's not the best Austin Powers film, but it's funny when it needs to be. It's what I'd call a really good time-waster.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Are you sure you don't have a little clone in you?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>IMDb mark: 6I don't understand why people like the Austin Powers movies so much. I don't understand why I like them. They are very silly, they are vulgar and they are rude. Or maybe that is exactly why I like them... 'Austin Powers in Goldmember' follows in the footsteps of the previous two incarnations and yet it still is appealing to the public. But I don't know whether the makers of the film are still mocking James Bond movies, or if they just saw that the series is a success and are trying to squeeze as much as they can out of it.-Humour: There are some great jokes in this movie. Many of them are just updates from the previous films, but there are some new ones, too, and the new ones are the best, in my opinion. The lines are still racy, of course. Look for the line I chose as the title of this review. 21/25-Physical Comedy: Not too many moments of physical comedy can be seen, given that the Austin Powers movies have always been about funny expressions with double meaning, which is why they are surely not as popular among people who don't speak English. Mike Myers and Verne Troyer, who plays Mini-Me, provide basically all of the physical comedy. They still couldn't find a funny female character, even though Beyonce Knowles is a bit better than the totally unfunny Elizabeth Hurley and Heather Graham. 7/20-Plot: By the way they advertised the movie, the plot was supposed to be that Austin goes back in time to save his father. But that really is a small part of the whole film, the rest being a sequence of events quite hard to follow logically. 4/15-Ending: I liked the ending a lot. Of course, taste varies. 9/10-Theme: A spy who has everything tries to get a little more and to save the world, while he's at it. But it's not a bad idea for a parody and, as long as it's funny, it's all good. 9/10-Nudity: There is no nudity in this film. 0/8-Cast: This is very impressive. Mike Myers in multiple roles, Beyonce Knowles, Seth Green and Michael Caine are all fairly well-known stars. But there are also great cameos, by Tom Cruise, Gwyneth Paltrow, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito, Steven Spielberg, Britney Spears, and more. 8/8-Genre: This is a comedy. 4/4--&gt;Overall: 62/100It's a good continuation of the previous two parts. I'm sure it won't disappoint the fans of the series. But the type of humour might not please everybody and, just for the record, my personal favourite is still part two, The Spy Who Shagged Me. From Swordlord, 1 sword up!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2004-02-12</date>
		<username>Blade_Le_Flambeur</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A weak follow up to a hilarious series</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Being a fan of the Austin Powers films, I anxiously awaited the release of the third film, 'Austin Powers in Goldmember'. I very much liked the parody of spy films (the James Bond series in particular), and I also liked some of the originality that Myers added in. However, I was heavily disappointed. On first glance, I enjoyed it, but on the second and third viewing, my opinion severely dropped. The characters from the previous two return, of course the main characters being Austin Powers (Mike Myers), Dr. Evil (Mike Myers), and Fat Bastard (Mike Myers). But this time, Austin Powers also plays a secondary villain, named Goldmember. The plot of the film is that Powers must stop Goldmember from using a satellite to destroy the world, and Dr. Evil from helping him. Along for the ride is Mini Me (Verne Troyer), Power's new sidekick Foxxy Cleoptra (Beyoncé Knowles), Scott Evil (Seth Green), and Nigel Powers (Michael Caine). The cast works out well, Myers does well (as always) as in the multiple roles, and Caine is a nice addition to the cast. However, the character of Cleoptra annoyed the hell out of me. It was the exact cliché 70's female action star, and she pretty much went through out the film practically yelling lame bits of dialogue. The script stooped, and it seems that not quite as much energy was put into the third as much as the first two. The film felt just.. dumb, there was no more of that hilarious original humor Myers managed to inject into the first two films. Instead, it's lame joke after lame joke after lame joke, and the humor gets much more raunchy. Fortunately, the film has its moments and Roach at least tries to hold the film together. 'Austin Powers in Goldmember' is a very disappointing end(?) to one of my favorite series. The humor just wasn't as good, and the film just lacked the creativity of the first two. 6/10</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2003-10-21</date>
		<username>GJBStar</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Weakest of the 3 but still fun (spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Austin Powers: Goldmember is the third film in the series and once again stars Mike Myers as several of the characters. In my opinion, it is probably the weakest of the three movies but also contains one of the best opening scenes I have seen in a film of this sort. We are used to Austin Powers films starting well but I feel in this case that the film does not build on its strong start and fails to capitalise on its momentum. By catching Doctor Evil early, the usual driving force behind the films is lost. Also, the Dr Evil-Mini Me song and dance echoing the second film is not as good as the previous incarnation.However, that is not to say that there are not good points in the film. Beyonce Knowles plays Foxxy Cleopatra well and is an improvement in leading ladies - she is funny and sexy as would be expected but also adds more meat and bite to the character than other "Austin girls". In particular, the Nathan Lane cameo scene is very funny. In addition, there are the usual amusing sight, flashback and language gags which still work as well as they did in the first movie.There are some characters that don't work in this one though. Michael Caine plays Nigel Powers, Austin's father and in my opinion is just a weak parody of his own persona. He appears happy and at ease hamming it up but he acts like he's in a joke that no-one else knows and too often is left without a laugh. Likewise, Goldmember is a weak character and there are periods of time where the movie goes by and he does nothing. Finally, Fred Savage as the mole. I just don't find the joke funny and it breaks up the narrative of the film too often.Overall, it is still a likeable movie and fans of the other Austin Powers movies will still like this, just maybe not as much. It is an easy, fun movie and as such, is watchable.6.5/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I must admit that I came to this film as a complete ?Austin Powers' novice and I was totally amazed when I discovered how many characters Mike Myers plays in this movie. This is an amazingly surreal movie and the gags are endless but what a pity so many of them are at the level of toilet humour. 	<review>
		<date>2003-07-31</date>
		<username>sddavis63 (revsdd@gmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>The Weakest Austin Powers Movie Is Still Fun</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As the title suggests, I think that the first two Austin Powers movies were better than this one. Having said that, what's really not to like about a movie that continues to have me laughing on a fairly regular basis every time I see it?Mike Myers has this part - or should I say these parts - down to a perfect "T." His portrayals of Austin and Dr. Evil are hilarious. In this movie he adds the character of Goldmember to the repertoire, and also reprises the role of Fat Bastard. It was only this latter part that I found him disappointing in. Fat Bastard wasn't nearly as funny as he was in the second of the series. I liked Michael Caine's portrayal of Austin's father Nigel, and the exploration of the relationship between the two, with a resolution that wasn't entirely a surprise. I did wonder why in the world it was felt necessary to open and close the movie with the portrayal of a fictional movie (within the movie) that Steven Spielberg was supposedly directing about Austin Powers' life. It gave the opportunity to allow for some cameo appearances by some big name actors (John Travolta, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito, Tom Cruise and Gwyneth Paltrow are all supposedly acting in this fictional movie) but it tended to confuse the issue a bit, and the cameos weren't really necessary; neither was the fictional movie integral at all to the actual movie.Having said that, there are some hilarious moments here. The fight between Austin and Mini-Me; the "shmoke and a pancake" scene which for some reason had me hooting; and the priceless physical that Austin undergoes on Dr. Evil's submarine. As per usual for Austin Powers, the humour is sometimes crude and sexual innuendo abounds, but this is nevertheless a very funny movie.7/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>possum-3</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Mike Myers is an untalented hack</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Not only does Myers have the habit of writing approximately twenty minutes of tepid material for every ninety minute movie, he also STEALS from people far more talented than himself! For those of who who think Myers is a genius and the Nathan Lane bit in this 'comedy' was funny, go dig up a copy of AFTER THE FOX, starring Peter Sellers and written by Neil Simon. You will see that Myers theft of this gag is an absolute sham and less than a pale imitation. In the original, it's clever, surreal, and very very funny. In Myers', it's turned senselessly around, badly done, and in such a way that it destroys the entire premise of the gag! Does Myers even know how to write comedy? Myers' best work was the first half of SO I MARRIED AN AXE MURDERER, he should have quit back then.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-05</date>
		<username>mrchaos33</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Over-the-top silliness</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you were a fan of the first two Austin Powers movies you're going to love Goldmember. It's a continuation of the over-the-top silliness that made the first two so popular. Many of the same elements are in place from picture to picture ? the forced perspective sight gags, the rapid fire banter between Dr. Evil and his son Scott, elaborate dance numbers ? but somehow instead of feeling like we've seen it before it seems fresh. For the most part it is Mike Myers (in four, count ?em, four roles this time) and his unerring sense of `the silly' that makes this material so watchable. Myers can push the envelope further than almost any other comic, and still come off as cute. Myers has elevated bathroom humour to high art. He's Benny Hill, not Tom Green. Destiny's Child lead singer Beyonce Knowles is Foxxy Cleopatra, Austin's love interest in Goldmember. This is her feature film debut, and she handles herself nicely. She doesn't have a great deal to do, but she has a lot of charisma and looks great on screen. The full Austin Powers' repertory company is back, Michael York, Robert Wagner, Verne `Mini-Me' Troyer and Seth Green, with some new faces added. I won't spoil the movie by giving away the cameos, but I will advise you to be on time and not miss the first 15 minutes of the movie.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Rejuvenated Powers</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>James Bond is so over the top anyway that any spoof needs to be completely ridiculous. To be fair, Mike Myers has never aimed for anything else, but the first Austen Powers film ran out of steam about halfway through. This, the third installment, is actually much better, relentlessly piling on inventive but terrible gags and aided by some hilarious celebrity cameos, with Michael Caine's self-parody the best. The humour is never less than crude (sample joke - first Japanese girl: "I am Fook Mi"; second Japanese girl: "And I am Fook Yu"). Yes, it's that awful, but somehow you still have to laugh. Better than it should be.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-04-15</date>
		<username>whatmoonlanding</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Embarrassing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is an embarrassing film. Mike Myers can do funny sketches but funny sketches do not a film make. Apart from the intro and the sketch where Austin stands on Mini Me's shoulders I can find nothing to recommend in this film. OK, colours and clothes, but those are fluff (get over Moulin Rouge, Australia). The script is weak and the whole thing goes from lame to embarassing in about 15 minutes. The only script jokes that aim above the teen belt are passe, post-modern cleverisms that aren't real wit since post-modernism is now a fact of life. On the whole, I like a bit of culture-bashing but there is no flattery in the imitations here, something that is essential for the humour to come out. It smacks of laziness to get into the psychology of the nation/character (Scheisse is German not Dutch for God's sake). The bashing comes across as mean, without being funny which is unforgiveable for 'comedy'. Add to that a lot of Myers self-indulgence and you'll cringe off your seat and leave early.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-04-13</date>
		<username>Victor Field</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Mr. Powers said it himself - "That is SO not funny."</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Austin Powers in Goldmember" starts off with Steven Spielberg directing "Austin Powers in Austinpussy" with Gwyneth Paltrow as Dixie Normous (har de har har) and Tom Cruise, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito and another well-known performer - not revealed until near the end - in the roles played by Mike Myers, Mike Myers, Verne Troyer and Mike Myers respectively (oh, all right - Austin Powers, Dr. Evil, Mini-Me and Goldmember). In fact, the movie's insistence on cramming in several cameos in the first ten minutes along with an overelaborate "Soul Bossanova" musical number indicates a motif that runs through the movie - self-indulgence.I purposely avoided "Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me" as part of my refusal to see anything involving the presence of Madonna, but this movie might not have been much worse had she been involved. The storyline of Dr. Evil retrieving Dutch criminal genius Goldmember from the past (why?) and having him kidnap Austin's father Nigel as part of his plan to flood the world just lies there - the problem is that the movie knows it's a rehash and a send-up, and in gleefully playing up its phoniness (not least in Fat Bastard's joke about wire fighting) there's barely a single sincere moment in the entire movie, a fatal mistake given that father-son relationships are a major plot point.The movie's knowledge of its repetitiveness doesn't excuse its laziness either; had the jokes been funny it would have been another matter, but too many are DOA, tasteless or both. Plus it's hard to ignore the suspicion that Myers is enjoying himself a lot more than the audience (what was the point of the "It's The Hard Knocks Life" number with Dr. Evil and Mini-Me?), and Goldmember himself is painful and surplus to requirements. It certainly does well on the eye-candy scale - Britney, Gwyneth, Beyonce Knowles - but other than Seth Green as Scott, the only time the movie genuinely works is when it goes to 1975 all too briefly, featuring the only time Beyonce sings on screen in the movie and the movie's one truly hilarious scene (involving our hero having to talk to her through Nathan Lane). And just when you think it can't get worse, up pop the Osbournes...Since even "1941" was better, it's too bad Spielberg didn't direct for real. (And if I were George S. Clinton - who scored all three movies - I'd not be too pleased at seeing Quincy Jones conduct the scoring orchestra in the opening.)</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-02-05</date>
		<username>Jacob Rosen (bix171@comcast.net)</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Bad, Very Bad</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The first seven minutes--a parody of `Mission: Impossible II'--is chock full of celebrities. After that, there's virtually no reason to keep watching--it's another `Saturday Night Live' sketch that goes on far too long. Mike Myers' indulgences remain as unchecked as ever which means that skits he thinks are funny, regardless of what anyone else might think, are included in all their humorless glory. Myers is probably the only comedian in movies today who doesn't seem to have the slightest notion about timing--all he wants to do is focus on scatological and homo jokes--and how he can be proud to deliver a comedy with so much dead air is beyond the ken of this reviewer. There are only two good lines and they are `Preparation H feels good on the whole' and `You're a cunning linguist and I am a master debater!' Now you don't have to watch.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2003-01-03</date>
		<username>Kelv-1</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The Best Austin Powers!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After the amazingly funny 'Austin Powers' and the average 'The Spy Who Shagged Me', everyone was wondering what could Mike Myers do to keep it fresh. Well, he made a damn good film that's for sure. World famous super spy Austin Powers (Mike Myers) is living a happy life in 2002. He has defeated Dr. Evil (Mike Myers again), put him and Mini-Me (Verne Troyer) behind bars and he is to be knighted. Things go wrong when his father, Nigel Powers (Michael Caine)is absent at the knighting ceremony and kidnapped by Goldmember (Mike Myers' newest role, a freaky Dutch disco dancer in 1975. Austin travels back to save his father and teams up with the sexy Foxxy Cleopatra (Beyonce Knowles). Between all this, there are a pair of Japanese twin sisters called Fook Mi and Fook Yu, a dance number which helps Dr. Evil escape, a crazy Sumo scene involving Fat Bastard (Mike Myers yet again) and a submarine in the shape of Dr. Evil himself. 'Goldmember' is the best film in the Austin Powers series and one of the best comedies of 2002 full stop. Everything from Goldmember trying to explain who Austin's Fahza is to Foxxy communicating to Austin through a hilarious Nathan Lane, every joke is milked out of the Austin Powers phenomenon and it's worth every penny. This film had me in tears with laughters. I mean, the smallest things like the way Dr. Evil and Frau (Mindy Sterling) say 'ya!' to each other or the fact that Scott (Seth Green) is so evil he's losing his hair had me rolling about the floor in laughter. Few comedies reach the near perfect mark but 'Goldmember' is one of them. To be honest, I wouldn't mind seeing an 'Austin Powers 4' right now considering how good this is. In the previous film, Mini-Me's scenes felt somewhat unsettling but here he is original and amusing. It's pure genius this film and to try to sum that up would be hard. The only part that really lets you down is Britney Spears' cameo. They were obviously just casting her to get a bigger audience. At least she had a funny joke during the end credits. Jay Roach returns behind the camera in what is his funniest film yet, and that's counting 'Meet the Parents'. Mike Myers and Michael McCullers once again write the screenplay and it's a real zinger. With cameos from everyone to Tom Cruise to John Travolta, it's sure to entertain!</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-12-29</date>
		<username>boondocksaint20</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Majorly Disapointing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Okay, the first movie, when I saw it was not that good, but over the years, it has become like a fine wine, in that it somehow, miraculously becomes funnier upon every viewing. The second one, in my opinion, was the crown jewel in the series. I saw that one on opening night and it brought the house down. Rarely have I ever laughed so hard at a movie. I can't explain why, but the second AP movie is extremely funny, and almost is worthy of the title of comedic genius. This entry, however, was a huge dispointment for many reasons.I, like many others on this site, got this as a Christmas present. I was really excited to see it since I missed it in theaters and I loved the second one so much. The simple truth is that this movie really isn't that funny. The opening is hilarious with all of the cameos, but then, it just goes downhill. There are a few scenes, however, that ARE laugh out loud hilarious, but they are few and far between, especially not what we would expect from an AP movie. These scenes, too, are mostly borrowed and expanded upon from other 'sight' gags from the first two, which were extremely funny. They're funny this time around, and are appropriately paid homage to, yet, when elaborations on existing jokes from previous sequels are the best part of a sequel, then something is terribly wrong. There is no plot in this one, though the other two had razor thin plots, at least they were coherent. This one, to me, made no sense. It seemed like too many scenes were tacked together or not well thought out. And the Goldmember character...totally not funny. I know, it was a shocker to me too, since Dr. Evil, and yes, even Fat Bastard, to me, were both incredibly hilarious. What was supposed to be funny about him? The fact that he speaks crappy English? The fact that he eats his own skin? The fact that people keep making 'Stupid Dutchman' remarks? The fact that the filmmakers thought we, the audience are too stupid and braindead to realize the difference between an inteligently played and scripted animated character, and a pathetic excuse for one? I think the latter of the four questions holds the most merit. And making Dr. Evil and Austin brothers? Congratulations! You've officially ruined the franchise! Yes, all of the old jokes and the times where Mini-Me gets the stuffing beating out of him weren't enough for them to ruin a good franchise, b\c now, they totally ruined the rivalry between Austin and argulably one of the funniest villans in movie history. Hopefully, they will read reviews like the ones on this site and NOT PURSUE an AP 4. I'm sorry, but Seth Green is not much of an actor and just can't compare with being the bad guy like Dr. Evil can.Overall, a below average movie. Why do I say this? Comedies are supposed to be funny. This is one of those movies that the producers knew that people would flock in droves to see just b\c of the title rather than the content. And they succeeded, since this movie made a boat-load full of cash. This series has run its course and has officially kicked the bucket. What amazes me is that word of mouth (usually reliable with movies) did not prevent millions upon millions of devoted fans and moviegoers alike to be treated to 95 minutes of bordom and pure disapointment. I rarely say this, but anyone who gives this movie better than average praise truly has no taste in movies. Trust me, there are silly AND intelligent movies out there (Naked Gun, Airplane, Monty Python and the Holy Grail, Blazing Saddles to name a few). This movie, save for a totally wasted Michael Caine, is totally recycled from the previous two movies. No originality at all. At least the first two had a sense of class to them. I am so shocked to see that this one has a 6.5 rating on IMDB! Maybe there truly is no hope left for Hollywood being able to dish out good movies anymore. For those of you who don't believe me, go ahead, I invite you to see for yourself who lame this one is, but if you do, make sure you rent it first and not buy it. If you made the same mistake as the person who got it for me did, you would be inadvertantly rewarding stupid and lethargic filmmakers who I know can do much better. Shame on you, Mike Myers! You have so much talent, and this is the best you can do? Well, maybe the last laugh is on me, since I know this one made mad cash at the box office, but if we as a society keep rewarding mediocrity, then that is what we will always receive. To be fair, I was thinking about giving it a 4/10 since it did make me laugh really hard about three times, but that rating is truly pushing it mainly b\c of the added disgust at knowing that I've been had and knowing that the filmmakers were capable, and compared to the previous two films, in a way, obligated to make a much better film. Overall, a complete waste of time. 3/10 stars. That is my story and I'm sticking to it.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-12-15</date>
		<username>Chris Sherlock</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Dreadful! Disgraceful! Just Plain Bad!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>All of the above correctly describe "Austin Powers in Goldmember." It is, by far, the worst of the three Austin Powers movies. The events of this movie--the revelation that Dr. Evil is Austin's brother, the transformation of Mini-Me from villain to good guy--seem to close the door on the possibility that there will be a fourth Austin Powers movie. Given the disaster that is "Goldmember", the potential lack of a sequel can only be viewed in a positive light.The far-too-numerous celebrity cameos (Donna D'Errico and a cast of thousands) seem to be nothing more than filler--they obviously didn't have enough of a story for the allotted time--and a distraction from the fact that "Goldmember" was little more than a recycled version of the first two movies. The philosophy behind "Goldmember" seems to have been, "Let's dust off the same old characters and have them do the same old things as they did in the first two movies and see if people still find it all entertaining." Granted, there were some variations in "Goldmember" on the first two Austin Powers movies. Beyonce Knowles was brought in as Foxy Cleopatra, the newest love interest for Austin, and Michael Caine appeared as Nigel Powers, Austin and Dr. Evil's father. Beyond that, "Goldmember" did not break much new ground, with the exception of the title character, a Dutch roller disco fan responsible for the kidnapping of Nigel Powers (Caine). Goldmember took a lot of the focus away from Dr. Evil who, in "Goldmember", seemed to be a mere shadow of the hilariously clueless dolt he was in previous Austin Powers movies.If you haven't seen "Goldmember" yet, do yourself a favor. Don't watch it. You'll have wasted 95 minutes that you won't be able to get back. Surely you have better things to do with your time.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-11-21</date>
		<username>Ronald Quincy Dobbs</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Disjointed and awful, definitely the worst movie all year.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Back in 1997 Austin Powers created quite a buzz as a really funny James Bond parody that was a sleeper hit, I saw it and thought it was incredibly original and generally laughed my ass off for the entire duration. The characters were incredibly entertaining and fun and the movie didn't feel forced.However, this movie is the definition of forced. In the very opening you get Tom Cruise and Gwyneth Paltrow doing a very very unfunny Austin Powers movie parody (Note to writers: Self parody does not work in a parody!), and the movie proceeds to Austin powers opening by dancing for no reason (you can't really level the same claim at the first one because the scene was appropriately goofy and relevant for what it was) and for whatever reason Austin walks in on Britney Spears's set and blows her head up. Huh? Oh yeah, and there's a LOT of product placement in this movie, a LOT, to the point where it's annoying the viewer.Some of the bits that would've been funny for instance some toilet humor involving a fountain and a shadow puppets scene behind a curtain would've been very funny if they didn't go on for like 10 minutes and seems to drag.I won't even bother ragging on Beyonce Knowle's acting because her lines were incredibly stupid to begin with and she didn't have a very significant role, either she is really that bad or she's just there to cash a check.Overall the main problem I have with this movie is that all the characters were basically destroyed by it and the series has self destructed while they already intend to make new ones. Goldmember picks at his skin, can bend into gross positions, and has well, a gold member. Why am i supposed to care about this character? Do they intend to make him a recurring villain, because he's awful. Dr. Evil and Scott pull a role reversal, Fat Bastard is stretched (pun intended) beyond the bounds of all stupidity in this one, and he was a really awful character to begin with.Stay away from this tripe, I can't even lay blame squarely on the writers because even Michael Caine and Mike Myers sounded wooden and were just rattling off catchphrases. Don't even bother spending money on a rental.</fullReview>
	</review>

Now that he has amused those of baser tastes, I challenge Myers to come up with something for his more intelligent fans. Shakespeare proved that you can write to the masses without disgusting others who prefer something more stimulating.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-09-20</date>
		<username>raysond</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wasn't the least bit funny......</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Whereas the difference in quality between,say,Jaws or Jaws 3-D,or perhaps Jaws:The Revenge or in particular any of the Friday the 13th horror flicks(not to mention The Nightmare of Elm Street trilogies)or Psycho,Psycho II or Psycho III:The Nurturing,can only be measured in light years within a third dimension,but the three films in Mike Myers' Austin Powers series have been remarkably consistent,each one alternately soaring and sinking for the same reasons indefinitely. In relating to the groovy adventures of the 60's-era British secret agent who finds himself transplanted in today's modern society,star-creator Myers and director Jay Roach will feature a great gag and then repeat it until its completely run into the ground;this modus operandi alternates with the pair likewise taking a terrible gag(usually soatological in nature)and milking it fior what little its worth and then some. If we must compare,the third(and possibly the last in the series for good)entry is not as better as the first installment,but not as sharp as the second. The high points will consist of a terrific opening sequence featuring several surprising cameos(including a few Oscar winners),the addition of Micheal Caine as Austin's spy daddy,and an expanded role for Verne Troyer,again stealing all the scenes as the diminutive Mini-Me. Myers,as usual,has plenty of opportunities to mug it up,playing not only Austin but also his ultra arch-nemesis Dr. Evil,returning as villain Fat Bastard and a new criminal mastermind known as Goldmember(the least not in my interest funny of the lot). His female companion is not very good(played by Beyonce Knowles in her feature film debut as Foxxy Cleopatra)since the female leads were as bad as the second installment which had Heather Graham and in the first one which had Elizabeth Hurley. The soundtrack to the film has little interest.How much you enjoy this will depend on your acceptance of the film's ratio of hit-to-miss nyuks.</fullReview>
	</review>
